DIV1.P: Much adoe about Nothing. As it hath been sundrie times publikely acted by the right honourable, the Lord Chamberlaine his seruants. Written by William Shakespeare.
LONDON Printed by V. S. for Andrew Wise, and William Aspley. 1600.

SP.STAGE: Enter Leonato gouernour of Messina, Innogen his wife, Hero his daughter, and Beatrice his neece, with a messenger.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato.
SP.P: I Learne in this letter, that don Peter of Arragon comes this night to Messina.

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.P: He is very neare by this, he was not three leagues off when I left him.

SP.SPEAKER: Leona.
SP.P: How many gentlemen haue you lost in this action?

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.P: But few of any sort, and none of name.

SP.SPEAKER: Leona.
SP.P: A victory is twice it selfe, when the atchiuer brings homeful numbers: I find here, that don Peter hath bestowed much honour on a yong Florentine called Claudio.

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.P: Much deseru'd on his part and equally remembred by don Pedro he hath borne himselfe beyond the promise of his age, doing in the figure of a lamb, the feats of a lion, he hath indeed better bettred expectation then you must expect of me to tell you how.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: He hath an vnckle here in Messina will be very much glad of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.P: I haue already deliuered him letters, and there ap∣peares much ioy in him, euen so much that ioy could not shew itselfe modest enough, without a badge of bitternesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Did he breake out into teares?

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.P: In great measure.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: A kind ouerflow of kindnesse, there are no faces truer then those that are so washt, how much better is it to weepe at ioy, then to ioy at weeping?

SP.SPEAKER: Beatr.
SP.P: I pray you, is Signior Mountanto returnd from the warres or no?

SP.SPEAKER: Messen.
SP.P: I know none of that name, ladie, there was none such in the army of any sort.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: What is he that you aske for neece?

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.P: My cosen meanes Signior Benedicke of Padua.

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.P: O hee's returnd, and as pleasant as euer he was.

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: He set vp his bills here in Messina, and challengde Cupid at the Flight, and my vncles foole reading the chalenge subscribde for Cupid, and challengde him at the Burbolt: I pray you, how many hath he kild and eaten in these warres? but how many hath he kild? for indeede I promised to eate all of his killing.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Faith neece you taxe Signior Benedicke too much, but heele be meet with you, I doubt it not.

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.P: He hath done good seruice lady in these warres.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: You had musty vittaile, and he hath holpe to eate it, he is a very valiaunt trencher man, he hath an excellent sto∣macke.

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.P: And a good souldier too, lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: And a good souldiour to a Lady, but what is he to a Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.P: A lord to a lord, a man to a man, stufft with al hono∣rable vertues.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: It is so indeed, he is no lesse then a stuft man, but for the stuffing wel, we are al mortall.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: You must not, sir, mistake my neece, there is a kind of mery warre betwixt Signior Benedicke and her, they neuer meet but there's a skirmish of wit betweene them.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P:
Alas he gets nothing by that, in our last conflict, 4 of his fiue wits went halting off, and now is the whole man gouernd with one, so that if he haue wit enough to keep himself warm, let him beare it for a difference between himself and his horse, for it is all the wealth that he hath left, to be known a reasona∣ble
creature, who is his companion now? he hath euery month a new sworne brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.P: Ist possible?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Very easily possible, he weares his faith but as the fa∣shion of his hat, it euer changes with the next blocke.

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.P: I see lady the gentleman is not in your bookes.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: No, and he were, I would burne my study but I pray you who is his companion? is there no yong squarer now that will make a voyage with him to the diuell?

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.P: He is most in the companie of the right noble Clau∣dio.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: O Lord, he will hang vpon him like a disease, hee is sooner caught than the pestilence, and the taker runs present∣ly madde, God help the noble Claudio, if he haue caught the Benedict, it will cost him a thousand pound ee a be cured.

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.P: I will holde friends with you Ladie.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Do good friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: You will neuer runne madde niece.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: No, not till a hote Ianuary.

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.P: Don Pedro is approacht.
SP.STAGE: Enter don Pedro, Claudio, Benedicke, Balthasar and Iohn the bastard.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: Good signior Leonato, are you come to meet your trouble: the fashion of the world is, to auoyd cost, and you in∣counter it.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Neuer came trouble to my house, in the likenesse of your grace; for trouble being gone, comfort should remaine: but when you depart from mee, sorrow abides, and happines takes his leaue.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: You embrace your charge too willingly: I thincke this is your daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: Her mother hath many times tolde me so.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: Were you in doubt sir that you askt her?

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: Signior Benedicke, no, for then were you a child.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P:
You haue it full Benedicke, wee may ghesse by this, what you are, being a man, truely the Lady fathers her selfe:
be happy Lady, for you are like an honourable father.

SP.SPEAKER: Be.
SP.P: If Signior Leonato be her father, she would not haue his head on her shoulders for all Messina as like him as she is.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: I wonder that you will still be talking, signior Bene∣dicke, no body markes you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: What my deere lady Disdaine! are you yet liuing?

SP.SPEAKER: Bea.
SP.P: Is it possible Disdaine should die, while she hath such meete foode to feede it, as signior Benedicke? Curtesie it selfe must conuert to Disdaine, if you come in her presence.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: Then is curtesie a turne-coate, but it is certaine I am loued of all Ladies, onelie you excepted: and I would I could finde in my heart that I had not a hard heart, for truely I loue none.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: A deere happinesse to women, they would else haue beene troubled with a pernitious suter, I thanke God and my cold blood, I am of your humour for that, I had rather heare my dog barke at a crow, than a man sweare he loues me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: God keepe your Ladiship stil in that mind, so some Gentleman or other shall scape a predestinate scratcht face.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Scratching could not make it worse, and twere such a face as yours were.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: Well, you are a rare parrat teacher.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: A bird of my tongue, is better than a beast of yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Ben.
SP.P: I would my horse had the speed of your tongue, and so good a continuer, but keep your way a Gods name, I haue done.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: You alwayes end with a iades tricke, I knowe you of olde.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: That is the summe of all: Leonato, signior Claudio, and signior Benedicke, my deere friend Leonato, hath inuited you all, I tell him we shall stay here, at the least a moneth and he heartily praies some occasion may detaine vs longer, I dare sweare he is no hypocrite, but praies from his heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: If you sweare my lord, you shall not be forsworne, let mee bidde you welcome, my lord, being reconciled to the Prince your brother: I owe you all duetie.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn
SP.P: I thanke you, I am not of many wordes, but I thanke yo

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Please it your grace leade on?

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: Your hand Leonato, we wil go together.

SP.SPEAKER: Clau.
SP.P: Benedicke, didst thou note the daughter of Signior Leonato?

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: I noted her not, but I lookte on her,

SP.SPEAKER: Clau.
SP.P: Is she not a modest yong ladie?

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: Do you question me as an honest man should doe, for my simple true iudgement? or would you haue me speake after my custome, as being a professed tyrant to their sex?

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: No, I pray thee speake in sober iudgement.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: Why yfaith me thinks shees too low for a hie praise, too browne for a faire praise, and too litle for a great praise, on∣lie this commendation I can affoord her, that were shee other then she is, she were vnhansome, and being no other, but as she is, I do not like her.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: Thou thinkest I am in sport, I pray thee tell mee truelie how thou lik'st her.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: Would you buie her that you enquier after her?

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: Can the world buie such a iewel?

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: Yea, and a case to putte it into, but speake you this with a sad brow? or doe you play the flowting iacke, to tell vs Cupid is a good Hare finder, and Vulcan a rare Carpenter: Come, in what key shall a man take you to go in the song?

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: In mine eie, shee is the sweetest Ladie that euer I lookt on.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: I can see yet without spectacles, and I see no such matter: theres her cosin, and she were not possest with a fury, exceedes her as much in beautie, as the first of Maie dooth the last of December: but I hope you haue no intent to turne hus∣band, haue you?

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: I would scarce trust my selfe, though I had sworne the contrarie, if Hero would be my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: Ist come to this? in faith hath not the worlde one man but he will weare his cappe with suspition? shall I neuer see a batcheller of three score againe? go to yfaith, and thou wilt needes thrust thy necke into a yoke, weare the print of it, and sigh away sundaies: looke, don Pedro is returned to seeke you.
SP.STAGE: Enter don Pedro, Iohn the bastard.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: What secret hath held you here, that you followed not to Leonatoes?

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: I would your Grace would constraine me to tell.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: I charge thee on thy allegeance.

SP.SPEAKER: Ben.
SP.P: You heare, Count Claudio, I can be secret as a dumb man, I woulde haue you thinke so (but on my allegiance, marke you this, on my allegiance) he is in loue, with who? now that is your Graces part: marke how short his answer is, with Hero Leonatoes short daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Clau.
SP.P: If this were so, so were it vttred.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: Like the olde tale, my Lord, it is not so, nor twas not so: but indeede, God forbid it should be so.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: If my passion change not shortly, God forbid it should be otherwise.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: Amen, if you loue her, for the Lady is very well worthy.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: You speake this to fetch me in, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: By my troth I speake my thought.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: And in faith, my Lord, I spoke mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: And by my two faiths and troths, my Lorde, I spoke mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Clau.
SP.P: That I loue her, I feele.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: That she is worthy, I know.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: That I neither feele how she should be loued, nor know how she should be worthie, is the opinion that fire can not melt out of me, I will die in it at the stake.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: Thou wast euer an obstinate heretique in the de∣spight of Beauty.

SP.SPEAKER: Clau.
SP.P: And neuer could maintaine his part, but in the force of his wil.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P:
That a woman conceiued me, I thanke her: that she brought me vp, I likewise giue her most humble thankes: but that I will haue a rechate winded in my forehead, or hang my bugle in an inuisible baldricke, all women shall pardon mee: because I will not doe them the wrong to mistrust any, I will doe my selfe the right to trust none: and the fine is, (for the
which I may go the finer,) I will liue a bacheller.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: I shall see thee ere I die, looke pale with loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: With anger, with sickenesse, or with hunger, my Lord, not with loue: proue that euer I loose more blood with loue then I will get againe with drinking, picke out mine eies with a Ballad-makers penne and hang me vp at the doore of a brothel house for the signe of blinde Cupid.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: Well, if euer thou dost fall from this faith, thou wilt prooue a notable argument.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: If I do, hang me in a bottle like a Cat, and shoote at me, and he that hits me, let him be clapt on the shoulder, and calld Adam.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: Well, as time shal trie: in time the sauage bull doth beare the yoake.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: The sauage bull may, but if euer the sensible Bene∣dicke beare it, plucke off the bulls hornes, and set them in my forehead, and let me be vildly painted, and in such great let∣ters as they write, here is good horse to hyre: let them signi∣fie vnder my signe, here you may see Benedicke the married man.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: If this should euer happen, thou wouldst be horn madde.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: Nay, if Cupid haue not spent all his quiuer in Ve∣nice, thou wilt quake for this shortly.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: I looke for an earthquake too then.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: Well, you will temporize with the howres, in the meane time, good signior Benedicke, repaire to Leonatoes, commend me to him, and tell him I will not faile him at sup∣per, for indeede he hath made great preparation.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: I haue almost matter enough in mee for suche an Embassage, and so I commit you.

SP.SPEAKER: Clau.
SP.P: To the tuition of God: from my house if I had it.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: The sixt of Iuly: your louing friend Benedicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: Nay mocke not, mocke not, the body of your dis∣course is sometime guarded with fragments, and the guardes are but slightly basted on neither, ere you flowt old ends any further, examine your conscience and so I leaue you.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: My liege, your Highnesse nowe may doe mee good.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.L: My loue is thine to teach, teach it but how,
And thou shalt see how apt it is to learne
Any hard lesson that may do thee good.

SP.SPEAKER: Clau.
SP.L: Hath Leonato any sonne, my lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.L: No childe but Hero, shees his onely heire:
Doost thou affect her Claudio?

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.L: O my lord,
When you went onward on this ended action,
I lookt vpon her with a souldiers eie,
That likt, but had a rougher taske in hand,
Than to driue liking to the name of loue:
But now I am returnde, and that warre-thoughts,
Haue left their places vacant: in their roomes,
Come thronging soft and delicate desires,
All prompting mee how faire yong Hero is,
Saying I likt her ere I went to warres.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.L: Thou wilt be like a louer presently,
And tire the hearer with a booke of words,
If thou dost loue faire Hero, cherish it,
And I wil breake with hir, and with her father,
And thou shalt haue her: wast not to this end,
That thou beganst to twist so fine a storie?

SP.SPEAKER: Clau.
SP.L: How sweetly you do minister to loue,
That know loues griefe by his complexion!
But lest my liking might too sodaine seeme,
I would haue salude it with a longer treatise.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.L: What need the bridge much broder then the flood?
The fairest graunt is the necessitie:
Looke what wil serue is fit: tis once, thou louest,
And I wil fit thee with the remedie,
I know we shall haue reuelling to night,
I wil assume thy part in some disguise,
And tell faire Hero I am Claudio,
And in her bosome ile vnclaspe my heart,
And take her hearing prisoner with the force
And strong incounter of my amorous tale:
Then after to her father will I breake,
And the conclusion is, she shal be thine,
In practise let vs put it presently.
SP.STAGE: Enter Leonato and an old man brother to Leonato

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: How now brother, where is my cosen your sonne hath he prouided this musique?

SP.SPEAKER: Old
SP.P: He is very busie about it, but brother, I can tell you strange newes that you yet dreampt not of.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Are they good?

SP.SPEAKER: Old
SP.P: As the euents stampes them but they haue a good co∣uer: they shew well outward, the prince and Count Claudio walking in a thicke pleached alley in mine orchard, were thus much ouer-heard by a man of mine: the prince discouered to Claudio that he loued my niece your daughter, and meant to acknowledge it this night in a daunce, and if he found her ac∣cordant, he meant to take the present time by the top, and in∣stantly breake with you of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo
SP.P: Hath the fellow any wit that told you this?

SP.SPEAKER: Old
SP.P: A good sharp fellow, I wil send for him, and question him your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: No, no, we wil hold it as a dreame til it appeare it self: but I will acquaint my daughter withall, that she may bee the better prepared for an answer, if peraduenture this be true: go you and tel hir of it: coosins, you know what you haue to doe, O I crie you mercie friend, go you with me and I wil vse your shill: good cosin haue a care this busie time.
SP.STAGE: Enter fir Iohn the bastard, and Conrade his companion.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: What the goodyeere my lord, why are you thus out of measure sad?

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn
SP.P: There is no measure in the occasion that breeds, ther∣fore the sadnesse is without limit.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: You should heare reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn
SP.P: And when I haue heard it, what blessing brings it?

SP.SPEAKER: Con
SP.P: If not a present remedy, at least a patient sufferance.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn
SP.P:
I wonder that thou (being as thou saist, thou art, borne vnder Saturne) goest about to apply a morall medicine, to a
mortifying mischiefe: I cannot hide what I am: I must be sad when I haue cause, and smile at no mans iests, eate when I haue stomack, and wait for no mans leisure: sleep when I am drow∣sie, and tend on no mans businesse, laugh when I am mery, and claw no man in his humor.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Yea but you must not make the full show of this till you may do it without controllment you haue of late stoode out against your brother, and he hath tane you newly into his grace, where it is impossible you should take true root, but by the faire weather that you make yourself, it is needful that you frame the season for your owne haruest.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn
SP.P: I had rather be a canker in a hedge, then a rose in his grace, and it better fits my bloud to be disdain'd of all, then to fashion a cariage to rob loue from any: in thi, (thogh I cannot be said to be a slatering honest man) it must not be denied but I am a plain dealing villaine, I am trusted with a mussel, and en∣fraunchisde with a ogge, therfore I haue decreed, not to sing in my cage: if I had my mouth I would bite: if I had my liber∣ty I would do my liking: in the mean time, let me be that I am, and seeke not to alter me.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Can you make no vse of your discontent?

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn
SP.P: I make all vse of it, for I vse it only,
Who comes here? what newes Borachio?

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P: I came yonder from a great supper, the prince your brother is royally entertain'd by Leonato, and I can giue you intelligence of an intended mariage.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn
SP.P: Wil it serue for any model to build mischiefe on? what is he for a foole that betrothes himselfe to vnquietnesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P: Mary it is your bothers right hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn
SP.P: Who, the most exquisite Claudio?

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P: Euen he.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn
SP.P: A proper squier, and who, and who, which way looks he?

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P: Mary one Hero the daughter and heire of Leonato.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn
SP.P: A very forward March-chicke, how came you to this?

SP.SPEAKER: Bor
SP.P: Being entertain'd for a perfumer, as I was smoaking a musty roome, comes me the prince and Claudio, hand in hand in sad conference: I whipt me behind the arras, and there heard it agreed vpon, that the prince should wooe Hero for himselfe, and hauing obtain'd her, giue her to Counte Clau∣dio.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn
SP.P: Come, come, let vs thither, this may proue food to my displeasure, that yong start vp hath all the glory of my ouer∣throw: if I can crosse him any way, I blesse my selfe euery way, you are both sure, and wil assist me.

SP.SPEAKER: Conr.
SP.P: To the death my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn
SP.P: Let vs to the great supper, their cheere is the greater that I am subdued, would the cooke were a my mind, shall we go proue whats to be done?

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P: Weele wait vpon your lordship.
SP.STAGE: Enter Leonato, his brother, his wife, Hero his daughter, and Beatrice his neece, and a kinsman.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: Was not counte Iohn here at supper?

SP.SPEAKER: brother
SP.P: I saw him not.

SP.SPEAKER: Beatrice
SP.P: How tartely that gentleman lookes, I neuer can see him but I am heart-burn'd an hower after.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.P: He is of a very melancholy disposition.

SP.SPEAKER: Beatrice
SP.P: He were an excellent man that were made iust in the mid-way between him and Benedick, the one is too like an image and saies nothing, and the other too like my ladies eldest sonne, euermore tatling.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: Then halfe signior Benedickes tongue in Counte Iohns mouth, and halfe Counte Iohns melancholy in Signior Benedickes face.

SP.SPEAKER: Beatrice
SP.P: With a good legge and a good foote vnckle, and money inough in his purse, such a man would winne any wo∣man in the world if a could get her good will.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: By my troth neece thou wilt neuer get thee a hus∣band, if thou be so shrewd of thy tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: brother
SP.P: Infaith shees too curst.

SP.SPEAKER: Beatrice
SP.P:
Too curst is more then curst, I shall lessen
Gods sending that way, for it is saide, God sends a curst cow short hornes, but to a cow too curst, he sends none.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: So, by being too curst, God will send you no hornes.

SP.SPEAKER: Beatrice
SP.P: Iust, if he send me no husband, for the which bles∣sing, I am at him vpon my knees euery morning and euening: Lord, I could not endure a husband with a beard on his face, I had rather lie in the woollen!

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: You may light on a husband that hath no beard.

SP.SPEAKER: Beatrice
SP.P: What should I do with him, dresse him in my ap∣parell and make him my waiting gentle woman? he that hath a beard, is more then a youth: and he that hath no beard, is lesse then a man: and he that is more then a youth, is not for me, and he that is lesse then a man, I am not for him, therefore I will euen take sixpence in earnest of the Berrord, and leade his apes into hell.

SP.SPEAKER: Lenoato
SP.P: Well then▪ go you into hell.

SP.SPEAKER: Beatrice
SP.P: No but to the gate, and there will the diuell meete me like an old cuckold with hornes on his head, and say, get you to heauen Beatrice, get you to heauen, heeres no place for you maids, so deliuer I vp my apes and away to saint Peter: for the heauens, he shewes me where the Batchellers sit, and there liue we as mery as the day is long.

SP.SPEAKER: brother
SP.P: Well neece, I trust you will be rulde by your fa∣ther.

SP.SPEAKER: Beatrice
SP.P: Yes faith, it is my cosens duetie to make cursie and say, father, as it please you: but yet for all that cosin, let him be a handsome fellow, or else make an other cursie, and say, father, as it please me.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: Well neece, I hope to see you one day fitted with a husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Beatrice
SP.P: Not til God make men of some other mettal then earth, would it not grieue a woman to be ouer-masterd with a peece of valiant dust? to make an account of her life to a clod of waiward marle? no vnckle, ile none: Adams sonnes are my brethren, and truely I holde it a sinne to match in my kin∣red.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: Daughter, remember what I told you, if the prince do solicite you in that kind, you know your answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Beatrice
SP.P: The fault will be in the musique cosin, if you be not wooed in good time: if the prince be too important, tell him there is measure in euery thing, and so daunce out the an∣swer, for here me Hero, wooing, wedding, and repenting, is as a Scotch ijgge, a measure, and a cinquepace: the first suite is hot and hasty like a Scotch ijgge (and ful as fantasticall) the wedding manerly modest (as a measure) full of state and aun∣chentry, and then comes Repentance, and with his bad legs falls into the cinquepace faster and faster, til he sincke into his graue.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: Cosin you apprehend passing shrewdly.

SP.SPEAKER: Beatrice
SP.P: I haue a good eie vnckle, I can see a church by day-light.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: The reuellers are entring brother, make good roome.
SP.STAGE: Enter prince, Pedro, Claudio, and Benedicke, and Balthaser, or dumb Iohn.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: Lady will you walke about with your friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.P: So, you walke softly, and looke sweetly, and say no∣thing, I am yours for the walke, and especially when I walk a∣way.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: With me in your company.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.P: I may say so when I please.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: And when please you to say so?

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.P: When I like your fauour, for God defend the lute should be like the case.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: My visor is Philemons roofe, within the house is Ioue.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.P: Why then your visor should be thatcht.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: Speake low if you speake loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: Well, I would you did like me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: So would not I for your owne sake, for I haue ma∣ny ill qualities.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: Which is one?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I say my praiers alowd.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: I loue you the better, the hearers may cry Amen.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: God match me with a good dauncer.

SP.SPEAKER: Balth.
SP.P: Amen.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: And God keepe him out of my sight when the daunce is done: answer Clarke.

SP.SPEAKER: Balth.
SP.P: No more words, the Clarke is answered.

SP.SPEAKER: Vrsula
SP.P: I know you well enough, you are signior Antho∣nio.

SP.SPEAKER: Antho.
SP.P: At a word I am not.

SP.SPEAKER: Ursula
SP.P: I knowe you by the wagling of your head.

SP.SPEAKER: Antho.
SP.P: To tell you true, I counterfeit him.

SP.SPEAKER: Vrsula
SP.P: You coulde neuer doe him so ill well, vnlesse you were the very man: heeres his drie hand vp and downe, you are he, you are he.

SP.SPEAKER: Antho.
SP.P: At a word I am not.

SP.SPEAKER: Ursula
SP.P: Come, come, do you thinke I do not know you by your excellent wit? can vertue hide it selfe? go to, mumme, you are he, graces will appeere, and theres an end.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Will you not tell me who tolde you so?

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: No, you shall pardon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Nor will you not tell me who you are?

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: Not now.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: That I was disdainefull, and that I had my good wit out of the hundred mery tales: wel, this was signior Benedick that said so.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: Whats he?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: I am sure you know him well enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: Not I, beleeue me.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Did he neuer make you laugh?

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: I pray you what is he?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Why he is the princes ieaster, a very dul fool only his gift is, in deuising impossible slaunders, none but Libertines delight in him, and the commendation is not in his wit, but in his villanie, for he both pleases men and angers them, and then they laugh at him, and beate him: I am sure he is in the Fleete, I would he had boorded me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: When I know the Gentleman, ile tell him what you say.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Do, do, heele but break a comparison or two on me, which peraduēture, (not markt, or not laught at) strikes him in∣to melancholy and then theres a partrige wing saued, for the foole will eate no supper that night: wee must follow the lea∣ders.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: In euery good thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Nay, if they leade to any ill, I will leaue them at the next turning.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn
SP.P: Sure my brother is amorous on Hero, and hath with∣drawne her father to breake with him about it: the Ladies fo∣low her, and but one visor remaines.

SP.SPEAKER: Borachio
SP.P: And that is Claudio, I knowe him by his bear∣ing.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn
SP.P: Are not you signior Benedicke?

SP.SPEAKER: Clau.
SP.P: You know me well, I am he.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn
SP.P: Signior, you are very neere my brother in his loue, he is enamourd on Hero, I pray you disswade him from her, she is no equall for his birth, you may doe the parte of an honest man in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: How know you he loues her?

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn
SP.P: I heard him sweare his affection.

SP.SPEAKER: Borac.
SP.P: So did I too, and he swore hee would marry her to night.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn
SP.P: Come let vs to the banquet.

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.L: Thus answer I in name of Benedicke,
But heare these ill newes with the eares of Claudio:
Tis certaine so, the Prince wooes for himselfe,
Friendship is constant in all other things,
Saue in the office and affaires of loue:
Therefore all hearts in loue vse their owne tongues.
Let euery eie negotiate for it selfe,
And trust no Agent: for Beauty is a witch,
Against whose charmes, faith melteth into blood:
This is an accident of hourely proofe,
Which I mistrusted not: farewel therefore Hero.

SP.SPEAKER: Benedicke
SP.P: Count Claudio.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: Yea, the same.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: Come, will you go with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: Whither?

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: Euen to the next willow, about your owne busines, county: what fashion will you weare the garland of? about your necke, like an Vsurers chaine? or vnder your arme, like a Lieutenants scarffe? you must weare it one way, for the prince hath got your Hero.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: I wish him ioy of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: Why thats spoken like an honest Drouier, so they sell bullockes: but did you thinke the Prince would haue ser∣ued you thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: I pray you leaue me.

SP.SPEAKER: Benedicke
SP.P: Ho now you strike like the blindman, twas the boy that stole your meate, and youle beate the post.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: If it will not be, ile leaue you.

SP.SPEAKER: Benedicke
SP.P: Alas poore hurt foule, now will hee creepe into sedges: but that my Ladie Beatrice should know me, and not know mee: the princes foole! hah, it may be I goe vnder that title because I am merry: yea but so I am apte to doe my selfe wrong: I am not so reputed, it is the base (though bitter) dispo∣sition of Beatrice, that puts the world into her person, and so giues me out: well, ile be reuenged as I may.
SP.STAGE: Enter the Prince, Hero, Leonato, Iohn and Borachio, and Conrade.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: Now signior wheres the Counte, did you see him?

SP.SPEAKER: Benedicke
SP.P: Troth my lord, I haue played the part of Ladie Fame, I found him heere as melancholy as a Lodge in a War∣ren, I tolde him, and I thinke I tolde him true, that your grace had got the goodwil of this yoong Lady and I offred him my company to a willow tree, either to make him a garland, as be∣ing forsaken, or to binde him vp a rod, as being worthie to bee whipt.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: To be whipt, whats his fault?

SP.SPEAKER: Benedicke
SP.P: The flatte transgression of a Schoole-boy, who being ouer-ioyed with finding a birds nest, shewes it his com∣panion, and he steales it.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P:
Wilt thou make a trust a transgression? the transgres∣sion
is in the stealer.

SP.SPEAKER: Benedicke
SP.P: Yet it had not beene amisse the rodde had beene made, & the garland too, for the garland he might haue worn himselfe, and the rodde he might haue bestowed on you, who (as I take it) haue stolne his birds nest.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: I wil but teach them to sing, and restore them to the owner.

SP.SPEAKER: Benedicke
SP.P: If their singing answer your saying, by my faith you say honestly.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: The ladie Beatrice hath a quarrell to you, the Gen∣tleman that daunst with her, told her shee is much wrongd by you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: O shee misusde me past the indurance of a blocke: an oake but with one greene leafe on it, would haue answered her: my very visor beganne to assume life, and scold with her: she tolde me, not thinking I had beene my selfe, that I was the Princes iester, that I was duller than a great thawe, huddleing iest vpon iest, with such impossible conuciance vpon me, that I stoode like a man at a marke, with a whole army shooting at me: she speakes poynyards, and euery word stabbes: if her breath were as terrible as her terminations, there were no liu∣ing neere her, shee would infect to the north starre: I woulde not marry her, though shee were indowed with al that Adam had left him before he transgrest, she would haue made Her∣cules haue turnd spit, yea, and haue cleft his club to make the fire too: come, talke not of her, you shall find her the infernall Ate in good apparell, I would to God some scholler woulde coniure her, for certainely while she is heere, a man may liue as quiet in hell, as in a sanctuarie, and people sinne vpon pur∣pose, because they would goe thither, so indeede all disquiet, horrour, and perturbation followes her.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: Looke heere she comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Benedicke
SP.P:
Will your grace command me any seruice to the worldes end? I will go on the slightest arrand now to the An∣typodes that you can deuise to send mee on: I will fetch you a tooth-picker now from the furthest inch of Asia: bring you
the length of Prester Iohns foot: fetch you a haire off the great Chams beard: doe you any embassage to the Pigmies, rather than holde three words conference, with this harpy, you haue no imployment for me?

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: None, but to desire your good company.

SP.SPEAKER: Benedicke
SP.P: O God sir, heeres a dish I loue not, I cannot in∣dure my Ladie Tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: Come Lady, come, you haue lost the heart of signi∣or Benedicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Beatrice
SP.P: Indeed my Lord, he lent it me awhile, and I gaue him vse for it, a double heart for his single one, mary once be∣fore he wonne it of me, with false dice, therefore your grace may well say I haue lost it.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: You haue put him downe Lady, you haue put him downe.

SP.SPEAKER: Beatrice
SP.P: So I would not he should do me, my Lord, lest I should prooue the mother of fooles: I haue brought Counte Claudio, whom you sent me to seeke.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: Why how now Counte, wherefore are you sad?

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: Not sad my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: How then? sicke?

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: Neither, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Beatrice
SP.P: The Counte is neither sad, nor sicke, nor merry, nor well: but ciuill Counte, ciuil as an orange, and something of that iealous complexion.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: I faith Lady, I think your blazon to be true, though ile be sworne, if he be so▪ his conceit is false: heere Claudio, I haue wooed in thy name, and faire Hero is won, I haue broke with her father, and his good will obtained, name the day of marriage, and God giue thee ioy.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: Counte take of me my daughter, and with her my fortunes: his grace hath made the match, and all grace say A∣men to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Beatrice
SP.P: Speake Counte, tis your Qu.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: Silence is the perfectest Herault of ioy, I were but little happy if I could say, how much? Lady, as you are mine, I am yours, I giue away my selfe for you, and doate vpon the exchange.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Speake cosin, or (if you cannot) stop his mouth with a kisse, and let not him speake neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: Infaith lady you haue a merry heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Beatr.
SP.P: Yea my lord I thanke it, poore foole it keepes on the windy side of Care, my coosin tells him in his eare that he is in her heart

SP.SPEAKER: Clau.
SP.P: And so she doth coosin.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Good Lord for aliance: thus goes euery one to the world but I, and I am sun-burnt, I may sit in a corner and crie, heigh ho for a husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: Lady Beatrice, I will get you one.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: I would rather haue one of your fathers getting: hath your grace ne re a brother like you? your father got excellent husbands if a maide coulde come by them.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Will you haue me? lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Beatr.
SP.P: No my lord, vnles I might haue another for work∣ing-daies, your grace is too costly to weare euery day: but I beseech your grace pardon me, I was born to speake all mirth, and no matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Your silence most offends me, and to be merry, best becomes you, for out a question, you were borne in a merry hower.

SP.SPEAKER: Beatr.
SP.P: No sure my lord, my mother cried, but then there was a starre daunst, and vnder that was I borne, cosins God giue you ioy.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: Neece, will you looke to those things I tolde you of?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat
SP.P: I crie you mercy vncle, by your graces pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: By my troth a pleasant spirited lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Theres little of the melancholy element in her my lord, she is neuer sad, but when she sleeps, & not euer sad then: for I haue heard my daughter say, she hath often dreampt of vnhappines, and wakt her selfe with laughing.

SP.SPEAKER: Pedro
SP.P: She cannot indure to heare tell of a husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: O by no meanes, she mockes al her wooers out of sute.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: She were an excellent wife for Benedick.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: O Lord, my lord, if they were but a weeke married, they would talke themselues madde.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Countie Claudio, when meane you to goe to church?

SP.SPEAKER: Clau.
SP.P: To morow my lord, Time goes on crutches, til Loue haue all his rites.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: Not til monday, my deare sonne, which is hence a iust seuennight, and a time too briefe too, to haue al things an∣swer my mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Come▪ you shake the head at so long a breathing, but I warrant thee Claudio, the time shall not go dully by vs, I wil in the interim, vndertake one of Hercules labors, which is, to bring Signior Benedick and the lady Beatrice into a moun∣taine of affection, th'one with th'other, I would faine haue it a match, and I doubt not but to fashion it, if you three will but minister such assistance as I shall giue you direction.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: My lord, I am for you, though it cost me ten nights watchings.

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: And I my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: And you too gentle Hero?

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.P: I wil do any modest office, my lord, to help my cosin to a good husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: And Benedicke is not the vnhopefullest husband that I know: thus farre can I praise him, he is of a noble strain, of approoued valour, and confirmde honesty, I will teach you how to humour your cosin, that she shall fal in loue with Be∣nedicke, and I, with your two helpes, wil so practise on Bene∣dicke, that in dispight of his quicke wit, and his queasie sto∣macke, he shall fall in loue with Beatrice: if we can do this, Cu∣pid is no longer an Archer, his glory shall bee ours, for we are the onely loue-gods, goe in with mee, and I will tell you my drift.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn
SP.P: It is so, the Counte Claudio shall marry the daughter of Leonato.

SP.SPEAKER: Bora.
SP.P: Yea my lord, but I can crosse it.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn
SP.P: Any barre, any crosse, any impediment, will be med∣cinable to me, I am sicke in displeasure to him, and whatsoeuer comes athwart his affection, ranges euenly with mine, how canst thou crosse this marriage?

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P: Not honestly my lord, but so couertly, that no disho∣nesty shall appeare in me.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn
SP.P: Shew me briefely how.

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P: I thinke I told your lordship a yeere since, how much I am in the fauour of Margaret, the waiting gentlewoman to Hero.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn
SP.P: I remember.

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P: I can at any vnseasonable instant of the night, appoint her to looke out at her ladies chamber window.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn
SP.P: What life is in that to be the death of this mariage?

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P: The poison of that lies in you to temper, goe you to the prince your brother, spare not to tell him, that he hath wronged his honor in marrying the renowned Claudio, whose estimation do you mightily hold vp, to a contaminated stale, such a one as Hero.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn
SP.P: What proofe shall I make of that?

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P: Proofe enough, to misuse the prince, to vexe Claudio, to vndoe Hero, and kill Leonato, looke you for any other issue?

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn
SP.P: Onely to dispight them I will endeuour any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P:
Go then, find me a meet houre, to draw don Pedro and the Counte Claudio alone, tell them that you know that Hero loues me, intend a kind of zeale both to the prince & Claudio (as in loue of your brothers honor who hath made this match) and his friends reputation, who is thus like to bee cosen'd with the semblance of a maid, that you haue discouer d thus: they wil scarcely beleeue this without triall: offer them instances which shall beare no lesse likelihood, than to see me at her chamber window, heare me call Margaret Hero, heare Marg terme me Claudio, & bring them to see this the very night before the in∣tended wedding, for in the mean time, I wil so fashion the mat∣ter, that Hero shal be absent and there shal appeere such seem∣ing truth of Heroes disloyaltie, that iealousie shal be cald assu∣rance
and al the preparation ouerthrowne.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn
SP.P: Grow this to what aduerse issue it can, I will put it in practise: be cunning in the working this, and thy fee is a thou∣sand ducates.

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P: Be you constant in the accusation, and my cunning shall not shame me.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn
SP.P: I will presently go learne their day of marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: Boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy
SP.P: Signior.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: In my chamber window lies a booke, bring it hither to me in the orchard.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: I am here already sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P:
I know that, but I would haue thee hence and here a∣gaine. I do much wonder, that one man seeing how much an other man is a foole, when he dedicates his behauiours to loue, wil after he hath laught at such shallow follies in others, becom the argument of his owne scorne, by falling in loue, and such a man is Claudio, I haue nowne when there was no musique with him but the drumme and the fife, and now had he rather heare the taber and the pipe: I haue knowne when he would haue walkt ten mile a foot, to see a good armour, and now wil he lie ten nights awake caruing the fashion of a new dublet: he was woont to speake plaine, and to the purpose (like an honest man and a souldier) and now is he turnd ortography, his words are a very fantasticall banquet, iust so many strange dishes: may I be so conuerted and see with these eies? I cannot tell, I thinke not: I wil not be sworne but loue may transforme me to an oyster, but ile take my oath on it, till he haue made and oy∣ster of me, he shall neuer make me such a foole: one woman is faire, yet I am well, an other is wise, yet I am well: an other vertuous, yet I am wel: but till all graces be in one woman, one womā shal not com in my grace: rich she shal be thats certain, wise, or ile none, vertuous, or ile neuer cheapen her: faire, or ile neuer looke on her, mild, or come not neare me, noble, or not I for an angell, of good discourse, an excellent musitian, and her
haire shall be of what colour it please God hah the prince and monsieur Loue, I wil hide me in the arbor.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Come shall we heare this musique?

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.L: Yea my good lord: how stil the euening is,
As husht on purpose to grace harmonie!

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: See you where Benedicke hath hid himselfe?

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.L: O very wel my lord: the musique ended,
Weele fit the kid-foxe with a penny worth.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Come Balthaser, weele heare that song againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Balth.
SP.L: O good my lord, taxe not so bad a voice,
To slaunder musicke any more then once.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.L: It is the witnesse still of excellencie,
To put a strange face on his owne perfection,
I pray thee sing, and let me wooe no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Balth.
SP.L: Because you talke of wooing I will sing,
Since many a wooer doth commence his sute,
To her he thinkes not worthy, yet he wooes,
Yet will he sweare he loues.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.L: Nay pray thee come,
Or if thou wilt hold longer argument,
Do it in notes.

SP.SPEAKER: Balth.
SP.L: Note this before my notes,
Theres not a note of mine thats worth the noting.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.L: Why these are very crotchets that he speakes,
Note notes forsooth and nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: Now diuine aire, now is his soule rauisht, is it not strange that sheepes guts should hale soules out of mens bo∣dies? well a horne for my mony when alls done.

LG.HEAD: The Song.
LG.L: Sigh no more ladies, sigh no more,
Men were deceiuers euer,
One foote in sea, and one on shore,
To one thing constant neuer,
Then sigh not so, but let them go,
And be you blith and bonnie,
Cng all your soundes of woe,
hey nony nony.
Sing no more ditties sing no moe,
O p so and heauy,
The fraud of men was euer so,
Sce first was leauy,
Then sg not so, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: By my trth a good song.

SP.SPEAKER: B.
SP.P: And singer my lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Ha , thou singst wel enough for a shift.

SP.SPEAKER: Ben.
SP.P: And bin a dog that should haue howld thus, they wu ave hangd him, and I pray God his bad voice o mscheefe, I had as liue haue heard the night-rauen, come wh plague could haue come after it.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Yea mary, doost thou heare Balthasar? I pray thee get some excellent musique: for to morow night we would haue it at the ladie Heroes chamber window.

SP.SPEAKER: Bal.
SP.P: The best I can my lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Do so, farewell. Come hither Leonato, what was it yu td mee of to day, that your niece Beatrice was in loue with snior Benedicke?

SP.SPEAKER: C
SP.P: O I, stalke on, stalk on, the foule sits. I did neuer think that lady would haue loued any man.

SP.SPEAKER: L
SP.P: No nor I neither, but most wonderful, that she should so dote on signior Benedicke, whome she hath in all outward bers seemd euer to abhorre.

SP.SPEAKER: Be.
SP.P: Ist possible? sits the wind in that corner?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: By my troth my Lord, I cannot tell what to thinke of it but that she loues him with an inraged affection, it is past the of thought.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: May be she doth but counterfeit.

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: Faith like enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: O God▪ counterfeit? there was neuer counterfeit of passion, came so neare the life of passion as she discouers it.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Why what effects of passion shewes she?

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: Baite the hooke wel, this fish will bite.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: What effects my Lord? she wil sit you, you heard my daughter tell you how.

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: She did indeede.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: How how I pray you! you amaze me, I would haue thought her spirite had beene inuincible against all assaults of affection.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I would haue sworn it had, my lord, especially against Benedicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: I should think this a gull, but that the white bearded fellow speakes it: knauery cannot sure hide himself in such re∣uerence.

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: He hath tane th' infection, hold it vp.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Hath shee made her affection knowne to Bene∣dicke?

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: No, and sweares shee neuer will, thats her tor∣ment.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: Tis true indeed, so your daughter saies: shall I, saies she, that haue so oft encountred him with scorne, write to him that I loue him?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: This saies she now when she is beginning to write to him, for sheel be vp twenty times a night, and there will she sit in her smocke til she haue writ a sheete of paper: my daughter tels vs all.

SP.SPEAKER: Clau.
SP.P: Now you talk of a sheet of paper, I remember a prety iest your daughter told of vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: O when she had writ it, and was reading it ouer, she found Benedicke and Beatrice betweene the sheete.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: That.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: O she tore the letter into a thousand halfpence, raild at her self, that she should be so immodest to write, to one that she knew would flout her, I measure him, saies she, by my own spirit, for I should flout him, if he writ to me, yea thogh I loue him I should.

SP.SPEAKER: Clau.
SP.P:
Then downe vpon her knees she falls, weepes, sobs, beates her heart, teares her haire, prayes, curses, O sweet Bene∣dicke,
God giue me patience.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: She doth indeed, my daughter saies so, and the ex∣tasie hath so much ouerborne her, that my daughter is some∣time afeard shee will doe a desperate out-rage to her selfe, it is very true.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: It were good that Benedicke knew of it by some o∣ther, if she will not discouer it.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: To what end: he would make but a sport of it, and torment the poore Lady worse.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: And he should, it were an almes to hang him shees an excellent sweete lady, and (out of all suspition,) she is vertu∣ous.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: And she is exceeding wise.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: In euery thing but in louing Benedicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: O my Lord, wisedome and blood combating in so tender a body, we haue ten proofes to one, that bloud hath the victory, I am sory for her, as I haue iust cause, beeing her vncle, and her gardian.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: I would shee had bestowed this dotage on mee, I would haue daft all other respects, and made her halfe my self: I pray you tell Benedicke of it, and heare what a will say.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: Were it good thinke you?

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: Hero thinkes surely she will die, for she sayes shee will die, if he loue her not, and shee will die ere shee make her loue knowne, and she will die if he wooe her rather than shee will bate one breath of her accustomed crosnese.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: She doth well, if shee shoulde make tender of her loue, tis very possible heele scorne it, for the man (as you know all) hath a contemptble spirite.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: He is a very proper man.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: He hath indeede a good outward happines.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: Before God, and in my mind, very wise.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Hee dooth indeede shew some sparkes that are like wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: And I take him to be valiant.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P:
As Hector, I assure you, and in the mannaging of quarrels you may say he is wise, for either hee auoydes them
with great discretion, or vndertakes them with a most christi∣anlike feare.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: If he do feare God, a must necessarily keep peace, if hee breake the peace, hee ought to enter into a quarrel with feare and trembling.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: And so will hee doe, for the man doth feare God, howsoeuer it seemes not in him, by some large iestes hee will make: well I am sory for your niece, shall we go seeke Bene∣dicke, and tell him of her loue?

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: Neuer tell him, my Lord, let her weare it out with good counsell.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: Nay thats impossible, shee may weare her heart out first.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Well, we will heare further of it by your daughter, let it coole the while, I loue Benedicke wel▪ and I could wish he would modestly examine himselfe, to see how much he is vnworthy so good a lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: My lord, will you walke? dinner is ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: If he do not doate on her vppon this, I will neuer trust my expectation

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Let there be the same nette spread for her, and that must your daughter and her gentlewomen carry: the sporte will be, when they holde one an opinion of an others dotage, and no such matter, thats the scene that I woulde see, which wil be meerely a dumbe shew: let vs send her to call him in to dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Benedicke
SP.P:
This can be no tricke, the conference was sdly borne▪ they haue the trueth of this from Hero, they seeme to pittie the Lady: it seemes her affections haue their full bent: loue me? why it must be requited: I heare how I am censurde, they say I will beare my selfe prowdly, if I perceiue the loue come from her: they say too that she will rather die than giue anie signe of affection: I did neuer thinke to marry, I must not seeme prowd, happy are they that heare their detractions, and can put them to mending: they say the Lady is faire, us a trueth, I can beare them witnesse: and vertuous, us so, I can∣not reprooue it, and wise, but for louing me, by my troth it is
no addition to her wit, nor no great argument of her follie, for I will be horribly in loue with her, I may chaunce haue some odde quirkes and remnants of witte broken on me, because I haue railed so long against marriage: but doth not the appe∣tite alter? a man loues the meate in his youth, that he cannot in∣dure in his age. Shall quippes and sentences, and these paper bullets of the brain awe a man from the carreere of his humor? No, the world must be peopled. When I saide I woulde die a batcheller, I did not think I should liue til I were married, here comes Beatrice: by this day, shees a faire lady, I doe spie some markes of loue in her.

SP.SPEAKER: Beatr.
SP.P: Aganst my will I am sent to bid you come in to din∣ner.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: Faire Beatrice, I thanke you for your paines.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: I tooke no more paines for those thankes, then you take paines to thanke me, if it had bin painful I would not haue come.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: You take pleasure then in the message.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Yea iust so much as you may take vppon a kniues point, and choake a daw withall: you haue no stomach signior, fare you well.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: Ha, against my will I am sent to bid you come in to dinner: theres a double meaning in that: I took no more paines for those thanks thē you took pains to thank me, thats as much as to say, any pains that I take for you is as easy as thanks: if I do not take pitty of her I am a villaine, if I do not loue her I am a Iew, I will go get her picture,
SP.STAGE: Enter Hero and two Gentlewomen, Margaret, and Ursley.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.L: Good Margaret runne thee to the parlour,
There shalt thou find my cosin Beatrice,
Proposing with the prince and Claudio,
Whisper her eare and tell her I and Vrsley,
Walke in the orchard, and our whole discourse
Is all of her, say that thou ouer-heardst vs,
And bid her steale into the pleached bowere
Where hony-suckles ripened by the sunne,
Forbid the sunne to enter: like fauourites,
Made proud by princes, that aduaunce their pride,
Against that power that bred it, there will she hide her,
To listen our propose, this is thy office,
Beare thee well in it, and leaue vs alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.L: Ile make her come I warrant you presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.L: Now Vrsula, when Beatrice doth come,
As we do trace this alley vp and downe,
Our talke must onely be of Benedicke,
When I do name him let it be thy part,
To praise him more than euer man did merite▪
My talke to thee must be how Benedicke,
Is sicke in loue with Beatrice: of this matter,
Is little Cupids crafty arrow made,
That onely wounds by heare-say: now begin,
For looke where Beatrice like a Lapwing runs
Close by the ground, to heare our conference.

SP.SPEAKER: Ursula
SP.L: The pleasantst angling is to see the fish
Cut with her golden ores the siluer streame,
And greedily deuoure the treacherous baite:
So angle we for Beatrice, who euen now,
Is couched in the wood-bine couerture,
Feare you not my part of the dialogue.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.L: Then go we neare her that her eare loose nothing,
Of the false sweete baite that we lay for it:
No truly Vrsula, she is too disdainfull,
I know her spirits are as coy and wild,
As haggerds of the rocke.

SP.SPEAKER: Ursula
SP.L: But are you sure,
That Benedicke loues Beatrice so intirely?

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.L: So saies the prince, and my new trothed Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Ursula
SP.L: And did they bid you tel her of it, madame?

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.L: They did intreate me to acquaint her of it,
But I perswaded them, if they lou'de Benedicke,
To wish him wrastle with affection,
And neuer to let Beatrice know of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Vrsula
SP.L: Why did you so, dooth not the gentleman
Deserue as full as fortunate a bed,
As euer Beatrice shall couch vpon?

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.L: O God of loue! I know he doth deserue,
As much as may be yeelded to a man:
But nature neuer framde a womans hart,
Of prowder stuffe then that of Beatrice:
Disdaine and Scorne ride sparkling in her eies,
Misprising what they looke on, and her wit
Valewes it selfe so highly, that to her
All matter els seemes weake: she cannot loue,
Nor take no shape nor proiect of affection,
She is so selfe indeared.

SP.SPEAKER: Vrsula
SP.L: Sure I thinke so,
And therefore certainely it were not good,
She knew his loue lest sheele make sport at it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.L: Why you speake truth, I neuer yet saw man,
How wise, how noble, yong, how rarely featured.
But she would spel him backward: if faire faced,
She would sweare the gentleman should be her sister:
If blacke, why Nature drawing of an antique,
Made a foule blot: if tall, a launce ill headed:
If low, an agot very vildly cut:
If speaking why a vane blowne with all winds:
If silent, why a blocke moued with none:
So turnes she euery man the wrong side out,
And neuer giues to Truth and Vertue, that
Which simplenesse and merite purchaseth.

SP.SPEAKER: Vrsula
SP.L: Sure, sure, such carping is not commendable.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.L: No not to be so odde, and from all fashions,
As Beatrice is, cannot be commendable,
But who dare tell her so? if I should speake,
She would mocke me into ayre, O she would laugh me
Out of my selfe presse me to death with wit,
Therefore let Benedicke like couerd fire,
Consume away in sighes, waste inwardly:
It were a better death, then die with mockes,
Which is as bad as die with tickling.

SP.SPEAKER: Vrsula
SP.L: Yet tel her of it, heare what she wil say.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.L: No rather I will go to Benedicke,
And counsaile him to fight against his passion,
And truly ile deuise some honest slaunders,
To staine my cosin with, one doth not know,
How much an ill word may impoison liking.

SP.SPEAKER: Vrsula
SP.L: O do not do your cosin such a wrong,
She cannot be so much without true iudgement,
Hauing so swift and excellent a wit,
As she is prisde to haue▪ as to refuse
So rare a gentleman as signior Benedicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.L: He is the onely man of Italy,
Alwaies excepted my deare Claudio.

SP.SPEAKER: Vrsula
SP.L: I pray you be not angry with me, madame,
Speaking my fancy: signior Benedicke,
For shape, for bearing argument and valour,
Goes formost in report through Italy.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.L: Indeed he hath an excellent good name.

SP.SPEAKER: Vrsula
SP.L: His excellence did earne it, ere he had it:
When are you married madame?

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.L: Why euery day to morrow, come go in,
Ile shew thee some attyres, and haue thy counsaile,
Which is the best to furnish me to morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Vrsula
SP.L: Shees limed I warrant you,
We haue caught her madame.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.L: If it proue so, then louing goes by haps,
Some Cupid kills with arrowes some with traps.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.L: What fire is in mine eares? can this be true?
Stand I condemn'd for pride and scorne so much?
Contempt, farewel, and maiden pride, adew,
No glory liues behind the backe of such.
And Benedicke, loue on I will requite thee,
Taming my wild heart to thy louing hand:
If thou dost loue, my kindnesse shall incite thee
To bind our loues vp in a holy band.
For others say thou dost deserue, and I
Beleeue it better then reportingly.
SP.STAGE: Enter Prince, Claudio, Benedicke, and Leonato.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: I doe but stay til your mariage be consummate, and then go I toward Arragon.

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: Ile bring you thither my lord, if youle vouchsafe me.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Nay that would be as great a soyle in the new glosse of your marriage, as to shew a child his new coate and forbid him to weare it, I wil only be bold with Benedick for his com∣pany, for from the crowne of his head, to the sole of his foot, he is al mirth, he hath twice or thrice cut Cupides bow-string, and the little hang-man dare not shoot at him, he hath a heart as sound as a bell, and his tongue is the clapper, for what his heart thinkes, his tongue speakes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: Gallants, I am not as I haue bin.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: So say I, me thinkes you are sadder.

SP.SPEAKER: Clau.
SP.P: I hope he be in loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Hang him truant, theres no true drop of bloud in him to be truly toucht with loue, if he be sadde, he wantes mo∣ney.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: I haue the tooth-ach.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Draw it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: Hang it.

SP.SPEAKER: Clau.
SP.P: You must hang it first, and draw it afterwards.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: What? sigh for the tooth-ach.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Where is but a humour or a worme.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: Wel, euery one cannot master a griefe, but he that has it.

SP.SPEAKER: Clau.
SP.P: Yet say I, he is in loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: There is no appeerance of fancie in him, vnlesse it be a fancy that he hath to strange disguises, as to be a Dutch-man to day, a French-man to morrow, or in the shape of two countries at once, as a Germaine from the waste downward, all slops, and a Spaniard from the hip vpward, no dublet: vn∣lesse he haue a fancie to this foolery, as it appeares he hath, he is no foole for fancy, as you would haue it appeare he is.

SP.SPEAKER: Clau.
SP.P: If he be not in loue with some woman, there is no be∣leeuing old signes, a brushes his hat a mornings, what should that bode?

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Hath any man seene him at the Barbers?

SP.SPEAKER: Clau.
SP.P: No, but the barbers man hath bin seene with him, and the olde ornament of his cheeke hath already stufft tennis balls.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Indeed he lookes yonger than he did, by the losse of a beard.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Nay a rubs himselfe with ciuit, can you smell him out by that?

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: Thats as much as to say, the sweete youthe's in loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: The greatest note of it is his melancholy.

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: And when was he woont to wash his face?

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Yea or to paint himselfe? for the which I heare what they say of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: Nay but his iesting spirit, which is now crept into a lute-string, and now gouernd by stops.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Indeed that tells a heauy tale for him: conclude, con∣clude he is in loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: Nay but I know who loues him.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: That would I know too, I warrant one that knows him not.

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: Yes, and his ill conditions, and in dispight of al, dies for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: She shall be buried with her face vpwards.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: Yet is this no charme for the tooth-ake, old signior, walke aside with me, I haue studied eight or nine wise wordes to speake to you, which these hobby-horses must not heare.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: For my life to breake with him about Beatrice.

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: Tis euen so, Hero and Margaret haue by this play∣ed their parts with Beatrice, and then the two beares will not bite one another when they meete.

SP.SPEAKER: Bastard
SP.P: My lord and brother, God saue you.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Good den brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Bastard
SP.P: If your leisure seru'd, I would speake with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: In priuate?

SP.SPEAKER: Bastard
SP.P: If it please you, yet Count Claudio may heare, for what I would speake of, concernes him.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Whats the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Bast.
SP.P: Meanes your Lordship to be married to morrow?

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: You know he does.

SP.SPEAKER: Bast.
SP.P: I know not that when he knowes what I know.

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: If there be any impediment, I pray you discouer it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bast.
SP.P: You may think I loue you not, let that appeare here∣after, and ayme better at me by that I now will manifest, for my brother (I thinke, he holdes you well, and in dearenesse of heart) hath holpe to effect your ensuing mariage: surely sute ill spent, and labor ill bestowed.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Why whats the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Bast.
SP.P: I came hither to tel you, and circumstances shortned, (for she has bin too long a talking of) the lady is disloyall.

SP.SPEAKER: Clau.
SP.P: Who Hero?

SP.SPEAKER: Bastar.
SP.P: Euen she, Leonatoes Hero, your Hero, euery mans Hero.

SP.SPEAKER: Clau.
SP.P: Disloyall?

SP.SPEAKER: Bast.
SP.P: The word is too good to paint out her wickednesse, I could say▪ she were worse, thinke you of a worse title, and I wil fit her to it: wonder not till further warrant: go but with me to night you shall see her chamber window entred, euen the night before her wedding day, if you loue her, then to morow wed her: But it would better fitte your honour to change your mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: May this be so?

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: I wil not thinke it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bast.
SP.P: If you dare not trust that you see, confesse not that you knowe: if you will follow mee, I will shew you enough, and when you haue seene more, and heard more, proceede ac∣cordingly.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: If I see anie thing to night, why I should not mar∣ry her to morrow in the congregation, where I should wed, there will I shame her.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: And as I wooed for thee to obtaine her, I wil ioyne with thee, to disgrace her.

SP.SPEAKER: Bastard
SP.P: I will disparage her no farther, till you are my wit∣nesses, beare it coldely but till midnight, and let the issue shew it selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: O day vntowardly turned!

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: O mischiefe strangely thwarting!

SP.SPEAKER: Bastard
SP.P: O plague right well preuented! so will you say, when you haue seene the sequele.
SP.STAGE: Enter Dogbery and his compartner with the Watch.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.P: Are you good men and true?

SP.SPEAKER: Uerges
SP.P: Yea, or else it were pitty but they should suffer sal∣uation body and soule.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.P: Nay, that were a punishment too good for them, if they should haue any allegeance in them, being chosen for the Princes watch.

SP.SPEAKER: Uerges
SP.P: Well, giue them their charge, neighbour Dog∣bery.

SP.SPEAKER: Dogbery
SP.P: First, who thinke you the most desartlesse man to be Constable?

SP.SPEAKER: Watch
SP.P: I Hugh Ote-cake sir, or George Sea-cole, for they can write and reade.

SP.SPEAKER: Dogbery
SP.P: Come hither neighbor Sea-cole, God hath blest you with a good name: to be a welfauoured man, is the gift of Fortune, but to write and reade, comes by nature.

SP.SPEAKER: Watch 2
SP.P: Both which maister Constable.

SP.SPEAKER: Dogbery
SP.P: You haue: I knew it would be your answer: wel, for your fauour sir, why giue God thanks, and make no boast of it, and for your writing and reading, let that appeere when there is no neede of such vanity, you are thought heere to be the most senslesse and fit man for the Constable of the watch: therefore beare you the lanthorne: this is your charge, You shall comprehend all vagrom men; you are to bidde any man stand, in the Princes name.

SP.SPEAKER: Watch 2
SP.P: How if a will not stand?

SP.SPEAKER: Dogbery
SP.P:
Why then take no note of him, but let him goe,
and presently call the rest of the watch together, and thanke god you are ridde of a knaue.

SP.SPEAKER: Verges
SP.P: If he wil not stand when he is bidden, he is none of the Princes subiects.

SP.SPEAKER: Dogbery
SP.P: True, and they are to meddle with none but the Princes subiects: you shall also make no noise in the streetes: for, for the watch to babble and to talke, is most tollerable, and not to be indured.

SP.SPEAKER: Watch
SP.P: We will rather sleepe than talke, we know what be∣longs to a watch.

SP.SPEAKER: Dogbery
SP.P: Why you speake like an antient and most quiet watchman, for I cannot see how sleeping should offend: one∣ly haue a care that your billes bee not stolne: well, you are to cal at al the alehouses, and bid those that are drunke get them to bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Watch
SP.P: How if they will not?

SP.SPEAKER: Dogbery
SP.P: Why then let them alone til they are sober, if they make you not then the better answer, you may say, they are not the men you tooke them for.

SP.SPEAKER: Watch
SP.P: Well sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Dogbery
SP.P: If you meete a thiefe, you may suspect him, by vertue of your office, to be no true man: and for such kind of men, the lesse you meddle or make with them, why the more is for your honesty.

SP.SPEAKER: Watch
SP.P: If we know him to be a thiefe, shal we not lay hands on him?

SP.SPEAKER: Dogbery
SP.P: Truely by your office you may, but I thinke they that touch pitch will be defilde: the most peaceable way for you, if you doe take a thiefe, is, to let him shew himselfe what he is, and steale out of your companie.

SP.SPEAKER: Uerges
SP.P: You haue beene alwayes called a mercifull manne, partner.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.P: Truely I would not hang a dogge by my will, much more a man who hath anie honestie in him.

SP.SPEAKER: Verges
SP.P: If you heare a child crie in the night you must call to the nurse and bid her stil it.

SP.SPEAKER: Watch
SP.P: How if the nurse be asleepe and will not heare vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.P: Why then depart in peace, and let the child wake her with crying, for the ewe that will not heare her lamb when it baes, will neuer answer a calfe when he bleates.

SP.SPEAKER: Verges
SP.P: Tis very true.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.P: This is the end of the charge: you constable are to present the princes owne person, if you meete the prince in the night, you may stay him.

SP.SPEAKER: Verges.
SP.P: Nay birlady that I thinke a cannot.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.P: Fiue shillings to one on twith any man that knowes the statutes, he may stay him, mary not without the prince be willing, for indeed the watch ought to offend no man, and it is an offence to stay a man against his will.

SP.SPEAKER: Uerges
SP.P: Birlady I thinke it be so.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.P: Ha ah ha, wel masters good night, and there be any matter of weight chaunces, cal vp me, keepe your fellowes counsailes, and your owne, and good night, come neigh∣bour.

SP.SPEAKER: Watch
SP.P: Well masters, we heare our charge, let vs goe sitte here vppon the church bench till twoo, and then all to bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.P: One word more, honest neighbors, I pray you watch about signior Leonatoes doore, for the wedding being there to morrow, there is a great coyle to night, a diew, be vigitant I be∣seech you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P: What Conrade?

SP.SPEAKER: Watch
SP.P: Peace, stir not.

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P: Conrade I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Here man, I am at thy elbow.

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P: Mas and my elbow itcht, I thought there would a scabbe follow.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: I will owe thee an answer for that, and now forward with thy tale.

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P: Stand thee close then vnder this penthouse, for it drissells raine, and I will, like a true drunckard, vtter all to thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Watch
SP.P: Some treason masters, yet stand close.

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P: Therefore know, I haue earned of Dun Iohn a thou∣sand ducates.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Is it possible that any villanie should be so deare?

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P: Thou shouldst rather aske if it were possible any vil∣lanie shuld be so rich? for when rich villains haue need of poor ones poore ones may make what price they will.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: I wonder at it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P: That shewes thou art vnconfirm'd, thou knowest that the fashion of a dublet, or a hat, or a cloake, is nothing to a man.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Yes it is apparell.

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P: I meane the fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Yes the fashion is the fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P: Tush, I may as well say the foole's the foole, but seest thou not what a deformed theefe this fashion is?

SP.SPEAKER: Watch
SP.P: I know that deformed, a has bin a vile theefe, this vij. yeere a goes vp and downe like a gentle man: I remember his name.

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P: Didst thou not heare some body?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: No, twas the vane on the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P: Seest thou not (I say what a deformed thiefe this fashi∣on is, how giddily a turnes about all the Hot-blouds, between foureteene and fiue and thirtie, sometimes fashioning them like Phataoes souldiours in the rechie painting, sometime like god Bels priests in the old church window, sometime like the shauen Hercules in the smircht worm-eaten tapestry, where his cod peece seemes as massie as his club.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Al this I see, and I see that the fashion weares out more apparrell then the man, but art not thou thy selfe giddy with the fashion too that thou hast shifted out of thy tale into telling me of the fashion?

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P:
Not so neither, but know that I haue to night wooed Margaret the Lady Heroes gentle-woman, by the name of Hero, she leanes me out at her mistris chamber window, bids me a thousand times good night: I tell this tale vildly I should first tel thee how the prince Claudio and my master planted▪ and placed, and possessed, by my master Don Iohn, saw a farre
off in the orchard this amiable incounter.

SP.SPEAKER: Conr.
SP.P: And thought they Margaret was Hero?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Two of them did, the prince and Claudio, but the di∣uel my master knew she was Margaret, and partly by his oths, which first possest them, partly by the darke night which did deceiue them, but chiefely, by my villany, which did confirme any slander that Don Iohn had made, away went Claudio en∣ragde, swore he would meet her as he was apointed next mor∣ning at the Temple, and there, before the whole congregation shame her, with what he saw o re night, and send her home a∣gaine without a husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Watch 1
SP.P: We charge you in the prince name stand.

SP.SPEAKER: Watch 2
SP.P: Call vppe the right maister Constable, wee haue here recouerd the most dangerous peece of lechery, that euer was knowne in the common wealth.

SP.SPEAKER: Watch 1
SP.P: And one Deformed is one of them, I know him, a weares a locke.

SP.SPEAKER: Conr
SP.P: Masters, masters.

SP.SPEAKER: Watch 2
SP.P: Youle be made bring deformed forth I warrant you.

SP.SPEAKER: Conr
SP.P: Masters, neuer speake, we charge you, let vs obey you to go with vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P: We are like to proue a goodly commoditie, being ta∣ken vp of these mens billes.

SP.SPEAKER: Conr.
SP.P: A commodity in question I warrant you, come weele obey you.
SP.STAGE: Enter Hero, and Margaret, and Vrsula.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.P: Good Vrsula wake my cosin Beatrice, and desire her to rise.

SP.SPEAKER: Ursula
SP.P: I wil lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.P: And bid her come hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Ursula
SP.P: Well.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Troth I thinke your other rebato were better.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.P: No pray thee good Meg, ile weare this.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: By my troth's not so good, and I warrant your cosin will say so.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.P:
My cosin's a foole, and thou art another, ile weare
none but this.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar
SP.P: I like the new tire within excelently, if the haire were a thought browner: and your gown's a most rare fashion yfaith, I saw the Dutchesse of Millaines gowne that they praise so.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.P: O that exceedes they say.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: By my troth's but a night-gown it respect of yours, cloth a gold and cuts, and lac d with siluer, set with pearles, downe sleeues, side sleeues, and skirts, round vnderborne with a blewish unsell, but for a fine queint graceful and excelent fa∣shion, yours is worth ten on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.P: God giue me ioy to weare it, for my heart is exceed∣ing heauy.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: T'will be heauier soone by the weight of a man.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.P: Fie vpon thee, art not ashamed?

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Of what lady? of speaking honourably? is not marri∣age honourable in a beggar? is not your Lord honourable without mariage? I thinke you would haue me say, sauing your reuerence a husband: & bad thinking do not wrest true spea∣king, ile offend no body, is there any harm in the heauier, for a husband? none I thinke, and it be the right husband, and the right wife, otherwise tis light and not heauy, aske my lady Bea∣trice els, here she comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.P: Good morrow coze.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Good morrow sweete Hero.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.P: Why how now? do you speake in the sicke tune?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: I am out of all other tune, me thinkes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar
SP.P: Clap's into Light a loue, (that goes without a burden,) do you sing it, and ile daunce it.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Ye Light alone with your heels, then if your husband haue stables enough youle see he shall lacke no barnes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: O illegitimate construction! I scorne that with my heeles.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Tis almost fiue a clocke cosin, tis time you were rea∣dy, by my troth I am exceeding ill, hey ho.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: For a hauke, a horse, or a husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: For the letter that begins them al, H.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Wel, and you be not turnde Turke, theres no more sayling by the starre.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: What meanes the foole trow?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Nothing I, but God send euery one their hearts de∣sire.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.P: These gloues the Counte sent me, they are an excel∣lent perfume.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: I am stuft cosin, I cannot smell.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: A maide and stuft! theres goodly catching of colde.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: O God help me, God help me, how long haue you profest apprehension?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Euer since you left it, doth not my wit become me rarely?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: It is not seene enough, you should weare it in your cap, by my troth I am sicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Get you some of this distill'd carduus benedictus, and lay it to your heart, it is the onely thing for a qualme.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.P: There thou prickst her with a thissel.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Benedictus, why benedictus? you haue some moral in this benedictus.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
