SP.P: Morall? no by my troth I haue no morall meaning, I meant plaine holy thissel, you may thinke perchaunce that I think you are in loue, nay birlady I am not such a foole to think what I list nor I list not to thinke what I can, nor indeed I can not think, if I would thinke my heart out of thinking, that you are in loue, or that you will be in loue, or that you can be in loue: yet Benedicke was such another and now is he become a man, he swore he would neuer marry, and yet now in dispight of his heart he eates his meate without grudging, and how you may be conuerted I know not, but me thinkes you looke with your eies as other women do.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: What pace is this that thy tongue keepes?

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Not a false gallop.

SP.SPEAKER: Ursula
SP.P:
Madame withdraw, the prince, the Count, signior Benedicke, Don Iohn, and all the gallants of the towne are
come to fetch you to church.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.P: Help to dresse me good coze, good Meg, good Vr∣sula.
SP.STAGE: Enter Leonato, and the Constable, and the Headborough.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: What would you with me, honest neighbour?

SP.SPEAKER: Const and Dog.
SP.P: Mary sir I would haue some confidence with you, that decernes you nearely.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: Briefe I pray you, for you see it is a busie time with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Const and Dog.
SP.P: Mary this it is sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Headb.
SP.P: Yes in truth it is sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: What is it my good friends?

SP.SPEAKER: Con and Do.
SP.P: Goodman Verges sir speaks a little of the matter, an old man sir, and his wittes are not so blunt, as God helpe I would desire they were, but infaith honest, as the skin between his browes.

SP.SPEAKER: Head.
SP.P: Yes I thank God, I am as honest as any man liuing, that is an old man, and no honester then I.

SP.SPEAKER: Const and Dog.
SP.P: Comparisons are odorous, palabras, neighbour Verges.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: Neighbors, you are tedious.

SP.SPEAKER: Const and Dog.
SP.P: It pleases your worship to say so, but we are the poore Dukes officers, but truly for mine owne part, if I were as tedious as a King I could find in my heart to bestow it all of your worship.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: Al thy tediousnesse on me, ah?

SP.SPEAKER: Const and Dog.
SP.P: Yea, and't twere a thousand pound more than tis, for I heare as good exclamation on your worshippe as of any man in the citie, and though I be but a poore man, I am glad to heare it.

SP.SPEAKER: Head.
SP.P: And so am I.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: I would faine know what you haue to say.

SP.SPEAKER: Head.
SP.P: Mary sir our watch to night, excepting your wor∣ships presence, ha tane a couple of as arrant knaues as any in Messina.

SP.SPEAKER: Const and Dog.
SP.P:
A good old man sir, he will be talking as they say, when the age is in, the wit is out, God help vs, it is a world
to see: well said yfaith neighbour Verges, well, God's a good man, and two men ride of a horse, one must ride behind, an ho∣nest soule yfaith sir, by my troth he is, as euer broke bread, but God is to be worshipt, all men are not alike, alas good neigh∣bour.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: Indeed neighbour he comes too short of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Const and Do.
SP.P: Gifts that God giues.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: I must leaue you.

SP.SPEAKER: Const and Dog.
SP.P: One word sir, our watch sir haue indeede com∣prehended two aspitious persons, and wee woulde haue them this morning examined before your worship.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: Take their examination your selfe and bring it me, I am now in great haste, as it may appeare vnto you.

SP.SPEAKER: Constable
SP.P: It shall be suffigance.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: Drinke some wine ere you goe: fare you well.

SP.SPEAKER: Messenger
SP.P: My lord, they stay for you, to giue your daugh∣ter to her husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Ile wait vpon them, I am ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Dogb.
SP.P: Go good partner▪ goe get you to Francis Sea-cole, bid him bring his penne and inckehorne to the Gaole: we are now to examination these men.

SP.SPEAKER: Verges
SP.P: And we must do it wisely.

SP.SPEAKER: Dogbery
SP.P: We will spare for no witte I warrant you: heeres that shall driue some of them to a noncome, only get the lear∣ned writer to set downe our excommunication, and meet me at the Iaile.
SP.STAGE: Enter Prince, Bastard, Leonato, Frier, Claudio, Bene∣dicke, Hero, and Beatrice.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: Come Frier Francis, be briefe, onely to the plaine forme of marriage, and you shall recount their particular due∣ties afterwards.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: You come hither, my lord, to marry this lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo
SP.P: To bee married to her: Frier, you come to marry her.

SP.SPEAKER: Frier
SP.P: Lady, you come hither to be married to this counte.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.P: I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Frier
SP.P:
If either of you know any inward impediment why
you should not be conioyned, I charge you on your soules to vtter it.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: Know you any, Hero?

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.P: None my lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Frier
SP.P: Know you any, Counte?

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: I dare make his answer, None.

SP.SPEAKER: Clau.
SP.P: O what men dare do! what men may do! what men daily do, not knowing what they do!

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: Howe nowe! interiections? why then, some be of laughing, as, ah, ha, he.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.L: Stand thee by Frier, father▪ by your leaue,
Will you with free and vnconstrained soule
Giue me this maide your daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Leonata
SP.P: As freely sonne as God did giue her mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.L: And what haue I to giue you backe whose woorth
May counterpoise this rich and pretious gift?

SP.SPEAKER: Prinn
SP.P: Nothing, vnlesse you render her againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.L: Sweete Prince, you learne me noble thankfulnes:
There Leonato, take her backe againe,
Giue not this rotten orenge to your friend,
Shee's but the signe and semblance of her honor:
Behold how like a maide she blushes heere!
O what authoritie and shew of truth
Can cunning sinne couer it selfe withall!
Comes not that blood, as modest euidence,
To witnesse simple Vertue? would you not sweare
All you that see her, that she were a maide,
By these exterior shewes? But she is none:
She knowes the heate of a luxurious bed:
Her blush is guiltinesse, not modestie.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: What do you meane my lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.L: Not to be married,
Not to knit my soule to an approoued wanton.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.L: Deere my lord, if you in your owne proofe,
Haue vanquisht the resistance of her youth,
And made defeate of her virginitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.L: I know what you would say: if I haue knowne her,
You will say, she did imbrace me as a husband,
And so extenuate the forehand sinne: No Leonato,
I neuer tempted her with word too large,
But as a brother to his sister, shewed
Bashfull sinceritie, and comelie loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.P: And seemde I euer otherwise to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.L: Out on thee seeming, I wil write against it,
You seeme to me as Diane in her Orbe,
As chaste as is the budde ere it be blowne:
But you are more intemperate in your blood,
Than Venus, or those pampred animalls,
That rage in sauage sensualitie.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.P: Is my Lord well that he doth speake so wide?

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: Sweete prince, why speake not you?

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.L: What should I speake?
I stand dishonourd that haue gone about,
To lincke my deare friend to a common stale.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: Are these things spoken, or do I but dreame?

SP.SPEAKER: Bastard
SP.P: Sir, they are spoken, and these things are true.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: This lookes not like a nuptiall.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.P: True, O God!

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.L: Leonato, stand I here?
Is this the prince? is this the princes brother?
Is this face Heroes? are our eies our owne?

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: All this is so, but what of this my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.L: Let me but moue one question to your daughter,
And by that fatherly and kindly power,
That you haue in her, bid her answer truly.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: I charge thee do so, as thou art my child.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.L: O God defend me how am I beset,
What kind of catechising call you this?

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: To make you answer truly to your name.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.L: Is it not Hero, who can blot that name
With any iust reproch?

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.L: Mary that can Hero,
Hero itselfe can blot out Heroes vertue.
What man was he talkt with you yesternight,
Out at your window betwixt twelue and one?
Now if you are a maide, answer to this.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.L: I talkt with no man at that hower my lord,

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.L: Why then are you no maiden. Leonato,
I am sory you must heare: vpon mine honor,
My selfe, my brother, and this grieued Counte
Did see her, heare her, at that howre last night,
Talke with a ruffian at her chamber window,
Who hath indeede most like a liberall villaine,
Confest the vile encounters they haue had
A thousand times in secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Iohn
SP.L: Fie, fie, they are not to be named my lord,
Not to be spoke of,
There is not chastitie enough in language,
Without offence to vtter them: thus pretty lady,
I am sory for thy much misgouernement.

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.L: O Hero! what a Hero hadst thou bin,
If halfe thy outward graces had bin placed,
About thy thoughts and counsailes of thy heart?
But fare thee well, most foule, most faire, farewell
Thou pure impietie, and impious puritie,
For thee ile locke vp all the gates of Loue.
And on my eie-liddes shall Coniecture hang,
To turne all beautie into thoughts of harme,
And neuer shall it more be gracious.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.L: Hath no mans dagger here a point for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Beatrice
SP.L: Why how now cosin, wherfore sinke you down?

SP.SPEAKER: Bastard
SP.L: Come let vs go: these things come thus to light,
Smother her spirits vp.

SP.SPEAKER: Benedicke
SP.L: How doth the Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Beatrice
SP.L: Dead I thinke, help vncle,
Hero, why Hero, vncle, signior Benedicke, Frier.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.L: O Fate! take not away thy heauy hand,
Death is the fairest couer for her shame
That may be wisht for.

SP.SPEAKER: Beatrice
SP.L: How now cosin Hero?

SP.SPEAKER: Frier
SP.L: Haue comfort lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.L: Dost thou looke vp?

SP.SPEAKER: Frier
SP.L: Yea, wherefore should she not?

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.L: Wherfore? why doth not euery earthly thing.
Cry shame vpon her? could she here deny
The story that is printed in her bloud?
Do not liue Hero, do not ope thme eies:
For did I thinke thou wouldst not quickly die,
Thought I thy spirites were stronger than thy shames,
My selfe would on the rereward of reproches
Strike at thy life. Grieued I I had but one?
Chid I for that at frugall Natures frame?
O one too much by thee! why had I one?
Why euer wast thou louely in my eies?
Why had I not with charitable hand,
Tooke vp a beggars issue at my gates,
Who smirched thus, and mired with infamy,
I might haue said, no part of it is mine,
This shame deriues it selfe from vnknowne loynes,
But mine and mine I loued, and mine I praisde,
And mine that I was prowd on mine so much,
That I my selfe▪ was to my selfe not mine:
Valewing of her, why she, O she is falne,
Into a pit of incke, that the wide sea
Hath drops too few to wash her cleane againe,
And salt too little, which may season giue
To her foule tainted flesh.

SP.SPEAKER: Ben.
SP.P: Sir, sir, be patient, for my part I am so attired in won∣der, I know not what to say.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.L: O on my soule my cosin is belied.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.L: Lady, were you her bedfellow last night?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.L: No truly, not although vntill last night,
I haue this tweluemonth bin her bedfellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: Confirmd, confirmd, O that is stronger made,
Which was before bard vp with ribs of yron,
Would the two princes lie, and Claudio lie,
Who loued her so, that speaking of her foulenesse,
Washt it with teares! hence from her, let her die.

SP.SPEAKER: Frier
SP.P: Heare me a little, for I haue only bin silent so long, & giuen way vnto this course of fortune, by noting of the lady, I haue markt,
SP.L: A thousand blushing apparitions,
To start into her face, a thousand innocent shames,
In angel whitenesse beate away those blushes,
And in her eie there hath appeard a fire,
To burne the errors that these princes hold
Against her maiden truth: call me a foole,
Trust not my reading, nor my obseruations,
Which with experimental seale doth warrant
The tenure of my booke: trust not my age,
My reuerence, calling, nor diuinitie,
If this sweete ladie lie not guiltlesse here,
Vnder some biting errour.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.L: Frier, it cannot be,
Thou seest that al the grace that she hath left,
Is, that she will not adde to her damnation,
A sinne of periury, she not denies it:
Why seekst thou then to couer with excuse,
That which appeares in proper nakednesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Frier
SP.L: Lady, what man is he you are accusde of?

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.L: They know that do accuse me, I know none,
If I know more of any man aliue
Then that which maiden modesty doth warrant,
Let all my sinnes lacke mercie, O my father,
Proue you that any man with me conuerst,
At houres vnmeete, or that I yesternight
Maintaind the change of words with any creature,
Refuse me, hate me, torture me to death.

SP.SPEAKER: Frier
SP.L: There is some strange misprision in the princes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.L: Two of them haue the very bent of honour,
And if their wisedomes be missed in this,
The practise of it liues in Iohn the Bastard,
Whose spirites toyle in frame of villanies.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.L: I know not, if they speake but truth of her,
These hands shall teare her, if they wrong her honour,
The prowdest of them shal wel heare of it.
Time hath not yet so dried this bloud of mine,
Nor age so eate vp my inuention,
Nor Fortune made such hauocke of my meanes,
Nor my bad life reft me so much of friends,
But they shall find awakte in such a kind,
Both strength of limbe, and policy of mind,
Ability in meanes, and choise of friends,
To quit me of them throughly.

SP.SPEAKER: Frier
SP.L: Pawse awhile,
And let my counsell sway you in this case,
Your daughter here the princesse (left for dead,)
Let her awhile be secretly kept in,
And publish it, that she is dead indeede,
Maintaine a mourning ostentation,
And on your families old monument,
Hang mourneful epitaphes, and do all rites,
That appertaine vnto a buriall.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: What shall become of this? what will this do?

SP.SPEAKER: Frier
SP.L: Mary this well caried, shall on her behalfe,
Change slaunder to remorse, that is some good,
But not for that dreame I on this strange course,
But on this trauaile looke for greater birth:
She dying, as it must be so maintaind,
Vpon the instant that she was accusde,
Shal be lamented, pittied, and excusde
Of euery hearer: for it so falls out,
That what we haue, we prize not to the worth,
Whiles we enioy it, but being lackt and lost,
Why then we racke the valew, then we find
The vertue that possession would not shew vs
Whiles it was ours, so will it fare with Claudio:
When hee shall heare she died vpon his words,
Th Idaea of her life shall sweetly creepe,
Into his study of imagination,
And euery louely Organ of her life,
Shall come apparelld in more precious habite,
More moouing delicate, and full of life,
Into the eie and prospect of his soule
Then when she liude indeed: then shall he mourne,
If euer loue had interest in his liuer,
And wish he had not so accused her:
No, though he thought his accusation true:
Let this be so, and doubt not but successe
Will fashion the euent in better shape,
Then I can lay it downe in likelihood.
But if all ayme but this be leuelld false,
The supposition of the ladies death,
Will quench the wonder of her infamie.
And if it sort not wel, you may conceale her,
As best befits her wounded reputation,
In some reclusiue and religious life,
Out of all eies, tongues, minds, and iniuries.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.L: Signior Leonato, let the Frier aduise you,
And though you know my inwardnesse and loue
Is very much vnto the prince and Claudio,
Yet, by mine honor, I will deale in this,
As secretly and iustly as your soule
Should with your body.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: Being that I flow in griefe,
The smallest twine may leade me.

SP.SPEAKER: Frier
SP.L: Tis wel consented, presently away,
For to strange sores, strangely they straine the cure,
Come lady die to liue, this wedding day
Perhaps is but prolong'd, haue patience and endure.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.L: Lady Beatrice, haue you wept al this while?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.L: Yea▪ and I will weep a while longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.L: I will not desire that.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.L: You haue no reason, I do it freely.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.L: Surely I do beleeue your faire consin is wronged.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Ah, how much might the man deserue of me that would right her!

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.L: Is there any way to shew such friendship?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.L: A very euen way, but no such friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.L: May a man do it?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.L: It is a mans office, but not yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P:
I doe loue nothing in the worlde so well as you,
is not that strange?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: As strange as the thing I knowe not, it were as possi∣ble for me to say, I loued nothing so wel as you, but beleue me not and yet I lie not, I confesse nothing, nor I deny nothing I am sory for my coosin.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: By my sword Beatrice, thou louest me.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Do not sweare and eate it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: I will sweare by it that you loue me, and I wil make him eate it that sayes I loue not you.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Will you not eate your word?

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: With no sawce that can be deuised to it, I protest I loue thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Why then God forgiue me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: VVhat offence sweete Beatrice?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: You haue stayed me in a happy houre, I was about to protest I loued you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: And do it with all thy heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: I loue you with so much of my heart, that none is left to protest.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: Come bid me doe any thing for thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Kill Claudio.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: Ha, not for the wide world.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: You kill me to deny it, farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: Tarry sweete Beatrice.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: I am gone, though I am here, there is no loue in you, nay I pray you let me go.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: Beatrice.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: In faith I will go.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: VVeele be friends first.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: You dare easier be friends with mee, than fight with mine enemy.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: Is Claudio thine enemy?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P:
Is a not approoued in the height a villaine, that hath slaundered, scorned, dishonored my kinswoman? O that I were a man! what, beare her in hand: vntill they come to take handes and then with publike accusation vncouerd slaunder, vnmittigated rancour? O God that I were a man! I woulde
eate his heart in the market place.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: Heare me Beatrice.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Talke with a man out at a window, a proper saying.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: Nay but Beatrice.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Sweete Hero, she is wrongd, she is slaundred, shee is vndone.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: Beat?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Princes and Counties! surely a princely testimonie, a goodly Counte, Counte Comfect, a sweete Gallant surely, O that I were a man for his sake! or that I had any friend woulde be a man for my sake! But manhoode is melted into cursies, valour into complement, and men are only turnd into tongue, and trim ones too: he is now as valiant as Hercules, that only tels a lie, and sweares it: I cannot be a man with wishing, ther∣fore I will die a woman with grieuing.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: Tarry good Beatrice, by this hand I loue thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Beatrice
SP.P: Vse it for my loue some other way than swearing by it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: Thinke you in your soule the Count Claudio hath wrongd Hero?

SP.SPEAKER: Beatrice
SP.P: Yea, as sure as I haue a thought, or a soule.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: Enough, I am engagde, I will challenge him, I will kisse your hand, and so I leaue you: by this hand, Claudio shal render me a deere account: as you heare of me, so think of me: goe comforte your coosin, I must say she is dead, and so fare∣well.
SP.STAGE: Enter the Constables, Borachio, and the Towne clearke in gownes.

SP.SPEAKER: Keeper
SP.P: Is our whole dissembly appeard?

SP.SPEAKER: Cowley
SP.P: O a stoole and a cushion for the Sexton.

SP.SPEAKER: Sexton
SP.P: Which be the malefactors?

SP.SPEAKER: Andrew
SP.P: Mary that am I, and my partner.

SP.SPEAKER: Cowley
SP.P: Nay thats certaine, we haue the exhibition to exa∣mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sexton
SP.P: But which are the offenders? that are to be exami∣ned let them come before maister constable.

SP.SPEAKER: Kemp
SP.P:
Yea mary, let them come before mee, what is your
name, friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P: Borachio.

SP.SPEAKER: Ke.
SP.P: Pray write downe Borachio. Yours sirra.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: I am a gentleman sir, and my name is Conrade.

SP.SPEAKER: Ke.
SP.P: Write downe maister gentleman Conrade: maisters, do you serue God?

SP.SPEAKER: Both
SP.P: Yea sir we hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Kem.
SP.P: Write downe, that they hope they serue God: and write God first, for God defend but God shoulde goe before such villaines: maisters, it is prooued alreadie that you are little better than false knaues, and it will go neere to be thought so shortly, how answer you for your selues?

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Mary sir we say, we are none.

SP.SPEAKER: Kemp
SP.P: A maruellous witty fellowe I assure you, but I will go about with him: come you hither sirra, a word in your eare sir, I say to you, it is thought you are false knaues.

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P: Sir, I say to you, we are none.

SP.SPEAKER: Kemp
SP.P: VVel, stand aside, fore God they are both in a tale: haue you writ downe, that they are none?

SP.SPEAKER: Sexton
SP.P: Master constable, you go not the way to examine, you must call foorth the watch that are their accusers.

SP.SPEAKER: Kemp
SP.P: Yea mary, thats the eftest way, let the watch come forth: masters, I charge you in the Princes name accuse these men.

SP.SPEAKER: Watch 1
SP.P: This man said sir, that don Iohn the Princes bro∣ther was a villaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Kemp
SP.P: Write downe prince Iohn a villaine: why this is flat periurie, to call a Princes brother villaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Borachio
SP.P: Maister Constable.

SP.SPEAKER: Kemp
SP.P: Pray thee fellowe peace, I doe not like thy looke I promise thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Sexton
SP.P: VVhat heard you him say else?

SP.SPEAKER: Watch 2
SP.P: Mary that he had receiued a thousand duckats of don Iohn, for accusing the Ladie Hero wrongfully.

SP.SPEAKER: Kemp
SP.P: Flat burglarie as euer was committed.

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.P: Yea by masse that it is.

SP.SPEAKER: Sexton
SP.P: VVhat else fellow?

SP.SPEAKER: Watch 1
SP.P: And that Counte Claudio did meane vppon his wordes, to disgrace Hero before the whole assemblie, and not marrie her.

SP.SPEAKER: Kemp
SP.P: O villaine! thou wilt be condemnd into euerlasting redemption for this.

SP.SPEAKER: Sexton
SP.P: VVhat else?

SP.SPEAKER: Watch
SP.P: This is all.

SP.SPEAKER: Sexton
SP.P: And this is more masters then you can deny, prince Iohn is this morning secretlie stolne awaie: Hero was in this manner accusde, in this verie manner refusde, and vppon the griefe of this sodamlie died: Maister Constable, let these men be bound, and brought to Leonatoes, I will goe before and shew him their examination.

SP.SPEAKER: Constable
SP.P: Come, let them be opiniond.

SP.SPEAKER: Couley
SP.P: Let them be in the hands of Coxcombe.

SP.SPEAKER: Kemp
SP.P: Gods my life, wheres the Sexton? let him write down the Princes officer Coxcombe: come, bind them, thou naugh∣ty varlet.

SP.SPEAKER: Couley
SP.P: Away, you are an asse, you are an asse.

SP.SPEAKER: Kemp
SP.P: Doost thou not suspect my place? doost thou not suspect my yeeres? O that he were here to write me downe an asse! but maisters, remember that I am an asse▪ though it bee not written downe, yet forget not that i am nasse: No thou villaine, thou art full of pretie as shal be prou de vpon thee by good witnes. I am a wise fellow, and which is more, an officer, and which is more, a housholder, and which is more, as pret∣ty a peece of flesh as anie is in Messina, and one that knowes the Law, goe to and a rich fellow enough, go to, and a fellow that hath had losses, and on that hath two gownes and euery thing hansome about him: bring him away: O that I had bin writ downe an asse!

SP.SPEAKER: Brother
SP.L: If you go on thus, you will kill your selfe,
And tis not wisedome thus to second griefe,
Against your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.L: I pray thee cease thy counsaile,
Which falles into mine eares as profitlesse,
As water in a syue: giue not me counsaile,
Nor let no comforter delight mine eare,
But such a one whose wrongs doe sute with mine.
Bring me a father that so lou'd his child,
Whose ioy of her is ouer-whelmd like mine,
And bid him speake of patience,
Measure his woe the length and bredth of mine,
And let it answer euery straine for straine,
As thus for thus, and such a griefe for such,
In euery lineament, branch, shape, and forme:
If such a one will smile and stroke his beard,
And sorrow, wagge, crie hem, when he should grone,
Patch griefe with prouerbes, make misfortune drunke,
With candle-wasters: bring him yet to me,
And I of him will gather patience:
But there is no such man, for brother, men
Can counsaile, and speake comfort to that griefe,
Which they themselues not feele, but tasting it,
Their counsaile turnes to passion, which before,
Would giue preceptiall medcine to rage,
Fetter strong madnesse in a silken thred,
Charme ach with ayre, and agony with words,
No, no, tis all mens office, to speake patience
To those that wring vnder the loade of sorrow
But no mans vertue nor sufficiencie
To be so morall, when he shall endure
The like himselfe: therefore giue me no counsaile,
My griefes crie lowder then aduertisement

SP.SPEAKER: Brother
SP.L: Therein do men from children nothing differ.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.L: I pray thee peace, I wil be flesh and bloud,
For there was neuer yet Philosopher,
That could endure the tooth-ake patiently,
How euer they haue writ the stile of gods,
And made a push at chance and sufferance.

SP.SPEAKER: Brother
SP.L: Yet bend not all the harme vpon your selfe,
Make those that do offend you, suffer too.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.L: There thou speakst reason, nay I will do so,
My soule doth tell me, Hero is belied,
And that shall Claudio know, so shall the prince,
And all of them that thus dishonour her.

SP.SPEAKER: Brother
SP.L: Here comes the Prince and Claudio hastily.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.L: Good den, good den.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.L: Good day to both of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.L: Heare you my Lords?

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.L: We haue some haste Leonato.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.L: Some haste my lord! well, fare you well my lord,
Are you so hasty now? wel, all is one.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.L: Nay do not quarrel with vs, good old man.

SP.SPEAKER: Brother
SP.L: If he could right himselfe with quarrelling,
Some of vs would lie low.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.L: Who wrongs him?

SP.SPEAKER: Leona.
SP.L: Mary thou dost wrong me, thou dissembler, thou:
Nay, neuer lay thy hand vpon thy sword,
I feare thee not.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.L: Mary beshrew my hand,
If it should giue your age such cause of feare,
Infaith my hand meant nothing to my sword.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.L: Tush, tush man, neuer fleere and iest at me,
I speake not like a dotard, nor a foole,
As vnder priuiledge of age to bragge,
What I haue done being yong▪ or what would doe,
Were I not old, know Claudio to thy head,
Thou hast so wrongd mine innocent child and me,
That I am forst to lay my reuerence by,
And with grey haires and bruise of many daies,
Do challenge thee to triall of a man,
I say thou hast belied mine innocent child.
Thy slander hath gone through and through her heart,
And she lies buried with her ancestors:
O in a toomb where neuer scandal slept,
Saue this of hers, framde by thy villanie.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.L: My villany?

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.L: Thine Claudio, thine I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.L: You say not right old man.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.L: My Lord, my Lord,
Ile prooue it on his body if he dare,
Dispight his nice fence, and his actiue practise,
His Maie of youth, and bloome of lustihood.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.L: A way, I will not haue to doe with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.L: Canst thou so daffe me? thou hast kild my child,
If thou kilst me, boy, thou shalt kill a man.

SP.SPEAKER: Brother
SP.L: He shal kill two of vs, and men indeed,
But thats no matter, let him kill one first:
Win me and weare me, let him answer me,
Come follow me boy, come sir boy, come follow me
Sir boy, ile whip you from your foyning fence,
Nay, as I am a gentleman I, will.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.L: Brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Brother
SP.L: Content your self, God knowes, I loued my neece,
And she is dead, slanderd to death by villaines,
That dare as well answer a man indeed,
As I dare take a serpent by the tongue,
Boyes, apes, braggarts, Jackes, milke-sops.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.L: Brother Anthony.

SP.SPEAKER: Brother
SP.L: Hold you content, what man! I know them, yea
And what they weigh, euen to the vtmost scruple,
Scambling, out-facing, fashion-monging boies,
That he, and cogge, and flout, depraue, and slaunder,
Go antiquely, and shew outward hidiousnesse,
And speake of halfe a dozen dang'rous words,
How they might hurt their enemies, if they durst,
And this is all.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.L: But brother Anthonie.

SP.SPEAKER: Brother
SP.L: Come tis no matter,
Do not you meddle, let me deale in this.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.L: Gentlemen both, we will not wake your patience,
My heart is sory for your daughters death:
But on my honour she was chargde with nothing
But what was true, and very full of proofe.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.L: My Lord, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.L: I will not heare you.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: No come brother, away, I wil be heard.

SP.SPEAKER: Bro.
SP.L: And shal, or some of vs wil smart for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.L: See see, heere comes the man we went to seeke.

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.L: Now signior, what newes?

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.L: Good day my Lord:

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Welcome signior, you are almost come to parte al∣most a fray.

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: Wee had likt to haue had our two noses snapt off with two old men without teeth.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Leonato and his brother what thinkst thou? had we sought, I doubt we should haue beene too yong for them.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: In a false quarrell there is no true valour, I came to seeke you both.

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: We haue beene vp and downe to seeke thee, for we are high proofe melancholie, and would faine haue it beaten away, wilt thou vse thy wit?

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: It is in my scabberd, shal I drawe it?

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Doest thou weare thy wit by thy side?

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: Neuer any did so, though very many haue been be∣side their wit, I will bid thee drawe, as wee doe the minstrels, w to pleasure vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: As I am an honest man he lookes pale, art thou sike, or angry?

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: What, courage man: what though care kild a catte, thou hast mettle enough in thee to kill care.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: Sir, I shall meete your wit in the careere, and you charge it against me, I pray you chuse another subiect

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: Nay then giue him another staffe, this last was broke crosse.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: By this light, he chaunges more and more, I thinke he be angry indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Claud
SP.P: If he be, he knowes how to turne his girdle.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: Shall I speake a word in your eare?

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: God blesse me from a challenge.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P:
You are a villaine, I ieast not, I will make it good howe you dare, with what you dare, and when you dare: doe mee right, or I will protest your cowardise: you haue killd a
sweeete Lady, and her death shall fall heauie on you, let me heare from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: Well I wil meet you, so I may haue good cheare.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: What, a feast, a feast?

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: I faith I thanke him he hath bid me to a calues head & a capon, the which if I doe not carue most curiously, say my kniffe's naught, shall I not find a woodcocke too?

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: Sir your wit ambles well, it goes easily.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Ile tell thee how Beatrice praisd thy witte the other day: I said thou hadst a fine witte, true said she, a fine little one: no said I, a great wit: right saies she, a great grosse one: nay said I, a good wit, iust said she, it hurts no body: nay said I, the gen∣tleman is wise: certaine said she, a wise gentleman: nay said I, he hath the tongues: that I beleeue said shee, for he swore a thing to mee on munday night, which hee forswore on tuesday mor∣ning, theres a double tongue theirs two tongues, thus did shee an houre together trans-shape thy particular vertues, yet at last she cōcluded with a sigh, thou wast the properst man in Italy.

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: For the which shee wept heartily and saide she ca∣red not.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Yea that she did, but yet for all that, and if she did not hate him deadly, she would loue him dearely, the old mans daughter told vs all.

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: All all, and moreouer, God sawe him when he was hid in the garden.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: But when shall we set the sauage bulles hornes one the sensible Benedicks head?

SP.SPEAKER: Clau.
SP.P: Yea and text vnder-neath, here dwells Benedick the married man.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: Fare you wel, boy, you know my minde, I wil leaue you now to your gossep-like humor, you breake iests as brag∣gards do their blades, which God be thanked hurt not: my Lord, for your many courtisies I thanke you, I must disconti∣nue your company, your brother the bastard is fled from Mes∣sina: you haue among you, kild a sweet and innocent lady: for my Lord Lacke beard, there hee and I shal meet, and till then peace be with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: He is in earnest.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: In most profound earnest, and ile warrant you, for the loue of Beatrice.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: And hath challengde thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: Most sincerely.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: What a pretty thing man is, when he goes in his dublet and hose, and leaues off his wit!

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: He is then a Giant to an Ape, but then is an Ape a Doctor to such a man.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: But soft you, let me be, plucke vp my heart, and be sad, did he not say my brother was fled?

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.P: Come you sir, if iustice cannot tame you, she shall nere weigh more reasons in her ballance, nay, and you be a cursing hypocrite once, you must be lookt to.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: How now, two of my brothers men bound? Bora∣chio one.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.P: Hearken after their offence my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Officers, what offence haue these men done?

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.P: Mary sir, they haue committed false report, moreo∣uer they haue spoken vntruths, secondarily they are slanders, sixt and lastly, they haue belyed a Lady, thirdly they haue ve∣refied vniust thinges, and to conclude, they are lying knaues.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince.
SP.P: First I aske thee what they haue done, thirdly I ask thee whats their offence, sixt and lastly why they are com∣mitted, and to conclude, what you lay to their charge.

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: Rightly reasoned, and in his owne diuision, and by my troth theres one meaning wel suted.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Who haue you offended maisters, that you are thus bound to your answere? this learned Constable is too cunning to be vnderstood, whats your offence?

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P:
Sweete prince, let me goe no farther to mine answere: do you heare me, and let this Counte kill me: I haue deceiued euen your very eyes: what your wisedoms could not discouer, these shallowe fooles haue broght to light, who in the night o∣erheard me confessing to this man, how Don Iohn your bro∣her incensed me to slaunder the Lady Hero, howe you were
brought into the orchard, and saw me court Margaret in He∣roes garments, how you disgracde hir when you should marry hir: my villany they haue vpon record, which I had rather seale with my death, then repeate ouer to my shame: the lady is dead vpon mine and my masters false accusation: and briefely, I de∣sire nothing but the reward of a villaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: Runnes not this speech like yron through your bloud?

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: I haue dronke poison whiles he vtterd it.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: But did my brother set thee on to this?

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.P: Yea, and paid me richly for the practise of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.L: He is composde and framde of treacherie,
And fled he is vpon this villanie.

SP.SPEAKER: Clau.
SP.L: Sweet Hero, now thy image doth appeare
In the rare semblance that I lou'd it first.

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.P: Come, bring away the plaintiffes, by this time our sexton hath reformed Signior Leonato of the matter: and ma∣sters, do not forget to specifie when time and place shal serue, that I am an asse.

SP.SPEAKER: Con. 2
SP.P: Here, here comes master Signior Leonato, and the sexton too.
SP.STAGE: Enter Leonato, his brother, and the Sexton.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.L: Which is the villaine? let me see his eies,
That when I note another man like him,
I may auoide him: which of these is he?

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.L: If you would know your wronger, looke on me.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.L: Art thou the slaue that with thy breath hast killd
Mine innocent child?

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.L: Yea, euen I alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: No, not so villaine, thou beliest thy selfe,
Here stand a paire of honourable men,
A third is fled that had a hand in it:
I thanke you Princes for my daughters death,
Record it with your high and worthy deeds,
Twas brauely done, if you bethinke you of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Clau.
SP.L: I know not how to pray your pacience,
Yet I must speake, choose your reuenge your selfe,
Impose me to what penance your inuention
Can lay vpon my sinne, yet sinnd I not,
But in mistaking.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.L: By my soule nor I,
And yet to satisfie this good old man,
I would bend vnder any heauy waight,
That heele enioyne me to.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.L: I cannot bid you bid my daughter liue,
That were impossible, but I pray you both,
Possesse the people in Messina here,
How innocent she died, and if your loue
Can labour aught in sad inuention,
Hang her an epitaph vpon her toomb,
And sing it to her bones, sing it to night:
To morrow morning come you to my house,
And since you could not be my son in law,
Be yet my nephew: my brother hath a daughter,
Almost the copie of my child thats dead,
And she alone is heyre to both of vs,
Giue her the right you should haue giu'n her cosin,
And so dies my reuenge.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.L: O noble sir!
Your ouer kindnesse doth wring teares from me,
I do embrace your offer and dispose,
For henceforth of poore Claudio.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.L: To morrow then I wil expect your comming,
To night I take my leaue, this naughty man
Shal face to face be brought to Margaret,
Who I beleeue was packt in al this wrong,
Hyred to it by your brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Bor.
SP.L: No by my soule she was not,
Nor knew not what she did when she spoke to me,
But alwayes hath bin iust and vertuous,
In any thing that I do know by her.

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.P:
Moreouer sir, which indeede is not vnder white and blacke, this plaintiffe heere, the offendour, did call me asse, I beseech you let it be remembred in his punishment, and also
the watch heard them talke of one Deformed, they say he weares a key in his eare and a locke hanging by it, and borows monie in Gods name, the which he hath vsde so long, & neuer paied, that now men grow hard hearted and wil lend nothing for Gods sake: praie you examine him vpon that point.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: I thanke thee for thy care and honest paines.

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.P: Your worship speakes like a most thankful and re∣uerent youth, and I praise God for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Theres for thy paines.

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.P: God saue the foundation.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Goe, I discharge thee of thy prisoner, and I thanke thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.P: I leaue an arrant knaue with your worship, which I beseech your worship to correct your selfe, for the example of others: God keepe your worship, I wish your worship well, God restore you to health, I humblie giue you leaue to depart and if a merie meeting may be wisht, God prohibite it: come neighbour.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Vntill to morrow morning, Lords, farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Brot.
SP.P: Farewell my lords, we looke for you to morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: We will not faile.

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.P: To night ile mourne with Hero.

SP.SPEAKER: Leonato
SP.P: Bring you these fellowes on, weel talke with Mar∣garet, how her acquaintance grew with this lewd felow.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.P: Praie thee sweete mistris Margaret, deserue well at my hands by helping me to the speech of Beatrice.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Wil you then write me a sonnet in praise of my beau∣tie?

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: In so high a stile Margaret, that no man liuing shall come ouer it, for in most comely truth thou deseruest it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: To haue no man come ouer me, why shal I alwaies keep below staires.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: Thy wit is as quicke as the grey-hounds mouth, it catches.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: And your's, as blunt as the Fencers foiles, which hit, but hurt not.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: A most manly witte Margaret, it will not hurt a wo∣man: and so I pray thee call Beatrice, I giue thee the buck∣lers.

SP.SPEAKER: Marg.
SP.P: Giue vs the swordes, wee haue bucklers of our owne.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: If you vse them Margaret, you must putte in the pikes with a vice, and they are daungerous weapons for maides.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Well, I will call Beatrice to you, who I thinke hath legges.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: And therefore wil come. The God of loue that sits aboue, and knowes mee, and knowes me, how pittifull I de∣serue. I meane in singing, but in louing, Leander the good swimmer, Troilus the first imploier of pandars, and a whole booke full of these quondam carpet-mongers, whose names yet runne smoothly in the euen rode of a blancke verse, why they were neuer so truly turnd ouer and ouer as my poore selfe in loue: mary I cannot shew it in rime, I haue tried, I can finde out no rime to Ladie but babie, an innocent rime: for scorne, horne, a hard rime: for schoole foole, a babling rime: very omi∣nous endings, no, I was not borne vnder a riming plannet, nor I cannot wooe in festiuall termes: sweete Beatrice wouldst thou come when I cald thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Yea signior, and depart when you bid me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: O stay but till then.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Then, is spoken: fare you wel now, and yet ere I goe, let me goe with that I came, which is, with knowing what hath past betweene you and Claudio.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: Onely foule words, and therevpon I will kisse thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Foule words is but foule wind, and foule wind is but foule breath, and foule breath is holsome, therfore I wil depart vnkist.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P:
Thou hast frighted the word out of his right sence, so forcible is thy wit, but I must tel thee plainly, Claudio vnder∣goes my challenge, and either I must shortly heare from him, or I will subscribe him a coward, and I pray thee now tell me,
for which of my bad parts didst thou first fal in loue with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: For them all together, which maintaind so politique a state of euil, that they will not admitte any good part to inter∣mingle with them: but for which of my good parts did you first suffer loue for me?

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: Suffer loue! a good epithite, I do suffer loue indeed, for I loue thee against my will.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: In spight of your heart I thinke, alas poore heart, if you spight it for my sake, I will spight it for yours, for I wil ne∣uer loue that which my friend hates.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: Thou and I are too wise to wooe peaceably.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: It appeares not in this confession, theres not one wise man among twentie that will praise himselfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: An old, an old instance Beatrice, that liu'd in the time of good neighbours, if a man do not erect in this age his owne toomb ere he dies, he shall liue no longer in monument, then the bell rings, and the widow weepes.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: And how long is that thinke you?

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: Question, why an hower in clamour and a quarter in rhewme, therefore is it most expedient for the wise, if Don worme (his conscience) find no impediment to the contrary, to be the trumpet of his owne vertues, as I am to my self so much for praising my selfe, who I my selfe will beare witnes is praise worthie, and now tell me, how doth your cosin?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Verie ill.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: And how do you?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Verie ill too.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: Serue God, loue me, and mend, there wil I leaue you too, for here comes one in haste.

SP.SPEAKER: Vrsula
SP.P: Madam, you must come to your vncle, yonders old coile at home, it is prooued my Lady Hero hath bin falsely ac∣cusde, the Prince and Claudio mightily abusde, and Don Iohn is the author of all, who is fled and gone: will you come pre∣sently?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: Will you go heare this newes signior?

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: I wil liue in thy heart, die in thy lap, and be buried in thy eies: and moreouer, I wil go with thee to thy vncles.
SP.STAGE: Enter Claudio, Prince, and three or foure with tapers.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.L: Is this the monument of Leonato?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord
SP.L: It is my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Epitaph.
SP.L: Done to death by slauderous tongues,
Was the Hero that heere lies:
Death in guerdon of her wronges,
Giues her fame which neuer dies:
So the life that dyed with shame,
Liues in death with glorious fame.
Hang thou there vpon the toomb,
Praising hir when I am dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.L: Now musick sound & sing your solemne hymne.

LG.HEAD: Song
LG.L: them, but I think they are more flexi Pardon goddesse of the night,
Those that slew thy virgin knight,
For the which with songs of woe,
Round about her tombe they goe:
Midnight assist our mone, help vs to sigh & grone.
Heauily heauily.
Graues yawne and yeeld your dead,
Till death be vttered,
Heauily heauily.

SP.SPEAKER: Lo.
SP.L: Now vnto thy bones good night, yeerely will I do this right.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.L: Good morrow maisters, put your torches out,
The wolues haue preied, and looke, the gentle day
Before the wheeles of Phoebus, round about
Dapples the drowsie East with spots of grey:
Thanks to you al, and leaue vs, fare you well.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.L: Good morrow masters, each his seuerall way.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.L: Come let vs hence, and put on other weedes,
And then to Leonatoes we will goe.

SP.SPEAKER: Claudio
SP.L: And Hymen now with luckier issue speeds,
Then this for whom we rendred vp this woe.
SP.STAGE: Enter Leonato, Benedick, Margaret Ursula, old man, Frier, Hero.

SP.SPEAKER: Frier
SP.L: Did I not tell you shee was innocent?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: So are the Prince and Claudio who accusd her,
Vpon the errour that you heard debated:
But Margaret was in some fault for this,
Although against her will as it appeares,
In the true course of all the question.

SP.SPEAKER: Old
SP.L: Wel, I am glad that all things sorts so well.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.L: And so am I, being else by faith enforst
To call young Claudio to a reckoning for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Well daughter, and you gentlewomen all,
Withdraw into a chamber by your selues,
And when I send for you come hither masked:
The Prince and Claudio promisde by this howre
To visite me, you know your office brother,
You must be father to your brothers daughter,
And giue her to young Claudio.

SP.SPEAKER: Old
SP.L: Which I will doe with confirmd countenance.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.L: Frier, I must intreate your paines, I thinke.

SP.SPEAKER: Frier
SP.L: To doe what Signior?

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.L: To bind me, or vndo me, one of them:
Signior Leonato, truth it is good Signior,
Your niece regards me with an eye of fauour.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: That eye my daughter lent her, tis most true.

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.L: And I do with an eye of loue requite her.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: The sight whereof I thinke you had from me,
From Claudio and the Prince, but whats your will?

SP.SPEAKER: Bened.
SP.L: Your answere sir is enigmaticall,
But for my wil, my will is, your good will
May stand with ours, this day to be conioynd,
In the state of honorable marriage,
In which (good Frier) I shal desire your help.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: My heart is with your liking.

SP.SPEAKER: Frier
SP.L: And my helpe.
Heere comes the Prince and Claudio.
SP.STAGE: Enter Prince, and Claudio, and two or three other.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.L: Good morrow to this faire assembly.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: Good morrow Prince, good morrow Claudio:
We heere attend you, are you yet determined,
To day to marry with my brothers daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.L: Ile hold my mind were she an Ethiope.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo
SP.L: Call her foorth brother, heres the Frier ready.

SP.SPEAKER: P.
SP.L: Good morrow Bened▪ why whats the matter?
That you haue such a Februarie face,
So full of frost, of storme, and clowdinesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.L: I thinke he thinkes vpon the sauage bull:
Tush feare not man weele tip thy hornes with gold,
And all Europa shall reioyce at thee,
As once Europa did at lustie loue,
When he would play the noble beast in loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.L: Bull Ioue sir had an amiable lowe,
And some such strange bull leapt your fathers cowe,
And got a calfe in that same noble feate,
Much like to you, for you haue iust his bleate.
SP.STAGE: Enter brother, Hero, Beatrice, Margaret, Ursula.

SP.SPEAKER: Clau.
SP.L: For this I owe you: here comes other recknings.
Which is the Lady I must seize vpon?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.L: This same is she, and I do giue you her.

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.L: Why then shees mine, sweet, let me see your face.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: No that you shall not till you take her hand,
Before this Frier, and sweare to marry hir.

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.L: Giue me your hand before this holy Frier,
I am your husband if you like of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.L: And when I liu'd I was your other wife,
And when you loued, you were my other husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Claud.
SP.L: Another Hero.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.L: Nothing certainer.
One Hero died defilde, but I do liue,
And surely as I liue, I am a maide.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.L: The former Hero, Hero that is dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: She died my Lord, but whiles her slaunder liu'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Frier
SP.L: All this amazement can I qualifie,
When after that the holy rites are ended,
Ile tell you largely of faire Heroes death,
Meane time let wonder seeme familiar,
And to the chappell let vs presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Ben.
SP.L: Soft and faire Frier, which is Beatrice?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.L: I answer to that name, what is your will?

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.L: Do not you loue me?

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.L: Why no, no more then reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.L: Why then your vncle, and the prince, and Claudio,
Haue beene deceiued, they swore you did.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.L: Do not you loue me?

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.L: Troth no, no more then reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.L: Why then my cosin Margaret and Vrsula
Are much deceiu'd, for they did sweare you did.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.L: They swore that you were almost sicke for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.L: They swore that you were welnigh dead for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.L: Tis no such matter, then you do not loue me.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.L: No truly, but in friendly recompence.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.L: Come cosin, I am sure you loue the gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Clau.
SP.L: And ile besworne vpon't, that he loues her,
For heres a paper written in his hand,
A halting sonnet of his owne pure braine,
Fashioned to Beatrice.

SP.SPEAKER: Hero
SP.L: And heres another,
Writ in my cosins hand, stolne from her pocket,
Containing her affection vnto Benedicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: A miracle, heres our owne hands against our hearts: come, I will haue thee, but by this light I take thee for pittie.

SP.SPEAKER: Beat.
SP.P: I would not denie you, but by this good day, I yeeld vpon great perswasion, and partly to saue your life, for I was told, you were in a consumption.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Peace I will stop your mouth.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince
SP.P: How dost thou Benedicke the married man?

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: Ile tel thee what prince: a colledge of witte-crackers cannot flout me out of my humour, dost thou think I care for a Satyre or an Epigramme? no, if a man will be beaten with braines, a shall weare nothing hansome about him: in briefe, since I doe purpose to marrie, I will think nothing to anie pur∣pose that the world can saie against it, and therfore neuer flout at me, for what I haue said against it: for man is a giddie thing, and this is my conclusion: for thy part Claudio, I did thinke to haue beaten thee▪ but in that thou art like to be my kinsman, liue vnbruisde, and loue my cousen.

SP.SPEAKER: Clau.
SP.P:
I had wel hopte thou wouldst haue denied Beatrice, that I might haue cudgelld thee out of thy single life, to make
thee a double dealer, which out of question thou wilt be, if my coosin do not looke exceeding narrowly to thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: Come, come, we are friends, lets haue a dance ere we are maried, that we may lighten our own hearts, and our wiues heeles.

SP.SPEAKER: Leon.
SP.P: Weele haue dancing afterward.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: First, of my worde, therefore plaie musicke, Prince, thou art sad, get thee a wife, get thee a wife, there is no staffe more reuerent then one tipt with horne.

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.L: My Lord, your brother Iohn is tane in flight,
And brought with armed men backe to Messina.

SP.SPEAKER: Bene.
SP.P: Thinke not on him till to morrow, ile deuise thee braue punishments for him: strike vp Pipers.
